column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: TUNIS, Tunisia - Tunisia, birthplace of the Arab Spring revolutionary movement, was plunged into a new political crisis Thursday when assassins shot an opposition party leader outside his home in a hail of gunfire.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: It was the second political assassination in Tunisia since February, and quickly incited protests blaming Ennahda, the moderate Islamist party that leads the government.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Crowds of protesters gathered outside the offices of the Interior Ministry in Tunis, the capital, calling on Ennahda to relinquish power, and security forces were deployed to contain them.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: The Associated Press reported that protests erupted in other cities, including Sidi Bouzid, the impoverished town where the Tunisian revolution began, and in the nearby town of Meknassi, where angry demonstrators burned down the local Ennahda headquarters.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Ennahda issued a statement calling the assassination “cowardly and despicable.” The leader of Ennahda, Rachid al-Ghannouchi, said on Tunisian radio: “This is a crime against the democratic transition of Tunisia.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: The classic question is: Who is behind this?

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: I don’t think that any political party would want this.”

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: TAP, Tunisia’s official news agency, said the victim was Mohamed Brahmi.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Brahmi, 58, leader of the Arab nationalist People’s Party, was felled by several bullets outside his residence in Ariana, a suburb of Tunis.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Other local Tunisian media said a pair of gunmen had shot Brahmi at least 11 times as he sat in a car with his daughter and that the killers escaped on a moped.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: At a hospital where Brahmi’s body was taken, dozens of protesters gathered to denounce Ennahda.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: “Ghannouchi is an assassin!” said a woman draped in a Tunisian flag.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Others shouted: “The Islamists are vampires!”

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: Noomen Toumi, one of the protesters at the hospital, said he believed Islamist extremists might have been behind the assassination of Brahmi.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: “It has to be someone who is against democracy,” he said.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: The assassination, which coincided with celebrations for the 56th anniversary of Tunisian statehood after independence from France, came as Tunisia was still grappling with a democratic transition following the January 2011 revolution that toppled the country’s autocratic leader, Zine El Abidine Ben Ali, and forced him into exile.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: The Tunisian revolution was the catalyst that spawned similar uprisings in Egypt, Libya, Yemen and Syria.

column2: SECOND OPPOSITION LEADER ASSASSINATED IN TUNISIA
column3: The top human rights official at the United Nations, Navi Pillay, expressed shock at the killing of Brahmi and urged “the authorities to immediately launch a prompt and transparent investigation to ensure that the people who carried out this crime are held accountable.”

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: A company alleged to have used deceptive practices to sell supplemental health insurance to veterans and other Massachusetts residents will pay more than $5 million to settle, Attorney General Martha Coakley said Tuesday.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: The settlement, now totaling $5.25 million, represents an increase of $1.5 million over an earlier agreement reached between Coakley’s office and Life Insurance Company of North America, in July 2012.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: The increase in restitution to consumers and penalties is a result of the insurer’s failure to meet the conditions of the original settlement, Coakley said.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: ''LINA’s failures to comply fully with its obligations under the consent judgment are unacceptable,'' Coakley said in a statement.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: ''This amendment will ensure that all Massachusetts consumers entitled to relief under the settlement will receive restitution from this company and will help further our ongoing efforts to ensure access to mental health services to veterans and their families.''

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: In a statement, the insurance company said it believes it complied with the provisions of the initial settlement and will continue to return premiums, as it has been doing, to affected Massachusetts residents.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: The amended accord, the company said, clarifies both parties’ understanding of the agreement.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: ''While the company agreed to pay a fine to avoid costly and time-consuming litigation,'' the statement added, ''the settlement recognizes LINA’s good-faith belief that it did not represent or market these products as 'health care insurance.'

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: Coakley’s initial complaint charged that the company used deceptive methods to market health insurance to veterans, especially those from World War II.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: It used direct mail and Internet solicitations to make the insurance appear to be a government program, exaggerating benefits, misrepresenting coverage limits, and making false claims about its rates, according to the attorney general’s office.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: It also denied coverage based on preexisting conditions, which is illegal in Massachusetts, according to the complaint.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: More than 1,000 Massachusetts consumers bought the policies, according to Coakley’s office.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: The initial settlement required the company to identify all consumers who had purchased supplemental insurance and refund premiums, minus any insurance claims paid by the insurer.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: But many customers have not received their payments, Coakley said.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: Coakley’s office went back to court to ensure the company would meet its obligations.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: In an amended settlement, the company agreed to pay an additional $750,000 in restitution to consumers, bringing the total to $3.5 million.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: It also agreed to pay an additional $375,000 in penalties and $375,000 to fund mental health services for veterans, on top of the $1 million in the original settlement.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: That brings the total the insurer has agreed to pay the state as a deterrent to $1.75 million, Coakley’s office said.

column2: Insurer's accord with state raised to $5.25 million
column3: Last month, with funds from the original settlement, the attorney general’s office awarded $500,000 in grants to five organizations to provide mental health services to veterans.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: LOS ANGELES - A year after Daniel Chong, a San Diego college student, was found hallucinating and suffering from kidney failure inside a Drug Enforcement Administration holding cell where he had been accidentally left for four days, the agency has agreed to compensate him for his ordeal.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: The federal government has agreed to pay Chong $4.1 million, Julia Yoo, one of his lawyers, said this week.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Chong’s lawyers filed a legal claim seeking $20 million last year.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: “It was an accident,” Chong, now 25, said at a news conference Tuesday to announce the settlement, “a really, really bad, terrible accident.”

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Chong was picked up last year during a raid on his friend’s house, where he and some friends had gathered to smoke marijuana.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Chong, a student at the University of California, San Diego, and the other suspects were taken to DEA offices, where he was interviewed.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Agents told Chong that he would be released, he said, and he was taken to a holding cell to wait for what he was told would be a few minutes.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Instead, he was forgotten inside the cell for four days.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Without food or water, he drank his own urine, contemplated taking his own life and tried to scratch a goodbye note to his mother into his arm.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: When agents found him on the fifth day, he thought he might be minutes from death.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: He spent several days in a hospital intensive care unit, where he was treated for severe dehydration and kidney failure.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: Over the past year, his lawyers said, he has continued to suffer from post-traumatic stress disorder.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: “His doctor said this was one of the worst cases of stress he had ever seen,” Eugene G. Iredale, one of Chong’s lawyers, said in an interview Wednesday.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: The DEA issued an apology shortly after Chong was found in the cell.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: A spokeswoman for the agency Wednesday refused to comment on the settlement but confirmed that the detention policies had been changed.

column2: SETTLEMENT FOR MAN LEFT IN DEA CELL
column3: The Office of the Inspector General in the Justice Department was reviewing the case.

3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: Three former high-ranking Penn State officials, including the university’s former president, Graham B. Spanier, were ordered Tuesday to stand trial on charges that they were part of a cover-up related to the child sexual abuse scandal involving former football coach Jerry Sandusky.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: After a two-day preliminary hearing this week, Harrisburg District Judge William Werner decided there was enough evidence against Spanier, retired university vice president Gary Schultz and former athletic director Tim Curley to proceed with a trial, which could start later this year.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: That would be the next public chapter of the scandal, which threw the university and its most prominent athletic program into turmoil.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: Two weeks ago, Penn State’s board of trustees authorized the payment of about $60 million to settle claims made by dozens of Sandusky’s victims.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: The numerous charges against the men include perjury, conspiracy and endangering the welfare of children.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: During the preliminary hearing, prosecutors accused the men of knowing of abuse allegations against Sandusky but failing to properly report them.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: They are also accused of hiding information from investigators and lying to a grand jury.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: The allegations stem from an incident in 2001, in which former Penn State assistant coach Mike McQueary said he saw Sandusky molesting a boy in a university shower.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: At Sandusky’s trial, McQueary testified that he reported the incident to Joe Paterno - Penn State’s famed former coach - Curley and Schultz.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: Curley and Schultz have said McQueary did not make it clear the act was sexual in nature.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: Spanier denied knowing the full nature of the incident.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: But emails between the three men revealed that Spanier, Curley and Schultz had decided in 2001 to confront Sandusky themselves, instead of reporting the allegations.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: “The only downside for us is if the message isn’t 'heard’ and acted upon, and we then become vulnerable for not having reported it,” Spanier wrote at the time.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: The emails also included discussion of abuse allegations against Sandusky from 1998.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: Spanier had testified to a grand jury that he had not been aware of the 1998 allegations.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: McQueary testified this week that Paterno had told him that the university botched its response to the Sandusky scandal and warned him that he would be made the scapegoat.

column2: 3 PENN STATE OFFICIALS ARE ORDERED TO STAND TRIAL
column3: McQueary said Paterno told him, “Old Main screwed up,” referencing the landmark campus building that houses the offices of the president and other administrators.

DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Pages from the diary of a chief Hitler aide, Alfred Rosenberg, missing since the conclusion of the Nuremberg trials of Nazi leaders nearly 70 years ago, were briefly displayed Thursday for the first time by the federal investigators who helped recover them.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: The diary, handwritten on loose-leaf pages with entries dating from 1936 through 1944, is likely to offer new insights into the decision to exterminate the Jews, infighting among top Nazi officials and the plunder of Europe’s art, said scholars at the U.S.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Holocaust Memorial Museum in Washington.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: It offers a window “into the mind of a dark soul,” said John T. Morton, director of the federal Immigration and Customs Enforcement agency, which investigates lost and stolen cultural property.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Although parts of Rosenberg’s diary are in the National Archives, and excerpts have been published in German, most of this first-person account remains unknown.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: The tangled journey of the diary could itself be the subject of a television mini-series.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: According to the Holocaust museum, after the trials ended, and Rosenberg was hanged in 1946, Robert M.W.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Kempner, a Nuremberg prosecutor, received permission from the office of the chief of counsel of war crimes to keep documents “for purposes of writing, lecturing and study.” With that brief approval in hand, Kempner took the diary, along with thousands of other documents, back to his home in Landsdowne, Pa.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: After Kempner died in 1993, the Holocaust museum negotiated a deal with his sons to collect his papers, said Henry Mayer, the museum’s senior adviser on archives.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Legal wrangling over the estate delayed the transfer, and when the museum finally picked up the documents in 1999, the diary and other materials were not among them.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Federal agents tracked a batch of missing papers to Herbert Richardson, an academic publisher and former professor in Lewiston, N.Y., and a friend of one of Kempner’s longtime secretaries.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: He turned over some documents, but the diary was not among them, Mayer explained.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: The museum kept up the search, and it led again to Richardson.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: He turned the pages over to federal agents in April, and the museum authenticated them.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: Morton declined to comment on the investigation, but he said that when the government’s civil forfeiture process was completed, the diary would be turned over to the museum.

column2: DIARY OF A HITLER AIDE RESURFACES AFTER A HUNT THAT LASTED YEARS
column3: There are “fewer and fewer living victims and witnesses to the horror of the Third Reich,” he said, which makes the original documents of that era all the more important.

JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: DETROIT - A federal bankruptcy judge on Wednesday cleared the way for Detroit’s bankruptcy case to go forward without legal challenges.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: The decision by Judge Steven Rhodes of U.S. Bankruptcy Court freezes all litigation against the city during the bankruptcy process and consolidates state-level legal challenges to Detroit’s Chapter 9 filing into the federal bankruptcy case.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: The federal bankruptcy court has “exclusive jurisdiction” over the case, he said, adding, “There is no case law that holds otherwise.”

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: It was a dramatic beginning to the largest municipal bankruptcy case in American history.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: The judge was attempting to put to rest a legal spat that began almost immediately after Detroit filed for bankruptcy last Thursday, the largest American city ever to do so.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: On Friday a state judge, Judge Rosemarie Aquilina of Ingham County Circuit Court, ruled that the filing violated the state constitution, which protects the pensions of retired public employees.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: The city has been expected to seek reductions in pensions in bankruptcy court as part of its broader efforts to reduce Detroit’s estimated $18 billion in debts and other obligations.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: Aquilina’s ruling was appealed by the state attorney general to the Michigan Court of Appeals, which on Tuesday issued a stay of her order pending their appellate decision.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: But on Wednesday, in the first hearing on the Chapter 9 case, Rhodes approved a motion by the city’s emergency financial manager, Kevyn D. Orr, to freeze all litigation against the city during the bankruptcy process.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: The move effectively gives Rhodes the authority to rule on the issues raised by retired public employees regarding their pensions.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: Rhodes also granted a second motion by the emergency manager that extends protection from litigation to Gov.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: Rick Snyder of Michigan and other state officials.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: Last week, Snyder accepted the city’s emergency manager’s recommendation and ordered Detroit to file for Chapter 9.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: Both Snyder and Orr have said that a bankruptcy filing was the only option to settle Detroit’s crushing debt.

column2: JUDGE CLEARS PATH FOR DETROIT BANKRUPTCY CASE
column3: As the case began, protesters gathered outside the federal courthouse downtown.

SLURS AGAINST BLACK OFFICIAL IN ITALY SPUR DEBATE ON RACISM
column3: ROME - When Cécile Kyenge accepted the post of minister of integration in Prime Minister Enrico Letta’s center-left government, she knew that as Italy’s first black national official she would be breaking new ground.

column2: SLURS AGAINST BLACK OFFICIAL IN ITALY SPUR DEBATE ON RACISM
column3: What she may not have expected was the stream of racial slurs that have accompanied her first eight weeks in office.

column2: GYULA HORN, WHO HELPED PART IRON CURTAIN, DIES AT 80

column2: GYULA HORN, WHO HELPED PART IRON CURTAIN, DIES AT 80

column2: GYULA HORN, WHO HELPED PART IRON CURTAIN, DIES AT 80

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION
column3: Bausch & Lomb, the eye care company, agreed Monday to sell itself to Valeant Pharmaceuticals International of Canada for about $8.7 billion, sidestepping the lengthier process of an initial public offering.

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

column2: VALEANT TO BUY BAUSCH & LOMB FOR $8.7 BILLION

SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: BEIRUT - Islamist extremists in Syria’s insurgency killed 150 soldiers in a battle for control of an Aleppo suburb this week, including 51 who were executed after they had surrendered, according to a Syrian monitoring group that has been chronicling casualties and evidence of atrocities.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: The group, the Britain-based Syrian Observatory for Human Rights, which sympathizes with the opposition and reports daily tallies of combat and violence from a network of contacts on the ground in Syria, corroborated its assertion Friday with a video posted on the Internet.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: The video, dated Wednesday, showed what appeared to be an execution ground, with dozens of lifeless bodies clumped against a wall pockmarked with bullet holes.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: The video’s authenticity could not be independently confirmed, but Rami Abdulrahman, the Syrian Observatory founder, quoted witnesses as saying 51 soldiers taken prisoner were later shot.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: Among the total who had surrendered, he said, “very few were taken hostage.”

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: Abdulrahman said the killers were members of the Nusra Front and Ansar al-Khalafa al-Islamiya Brigade, among the many jihadist groups, some affiliated with al-Qaida and populated with foreign fighters, that have entered Syria to join the insurgency battling the forces of President Bashar Assad in the conflict, now in its third year.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: If his assertions are confirmed, the killings would rank among the worst mass executions carried out by the rebel side and could aggravate the image problems for the coalition of insurgent forces, which are riven by internal conflict and have been losing territory to Assad’s side in recent weeks.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: At the United Nations on Friday, a delegation of Syrian opposition leaders met informally with Security Council members for the first time, to press their contention that Assad has no interest in negotiating a peace deal as long as he believes he is winning on the battlefield.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: Delegation members told reporters they had asked Russia, the Syrian government’s most powerful foreign backer, to stop supplying weapons to Assad.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: The delegation, led by the coalition’s newly elected president, Ahmed al-Jarba, met the day before with Secretary of State John Kerry during his visit to the United Nations and beseeched him to expedite U.S. military aid to opposition fighters.

column2: SOLDIERS' MASS EXECUTION REPORTED BY SYRIAN GROUP
column3: Al-Jarba has publicly rejected any alliance with the jihadists who have joined the insurgency and has repeatedly stressed what he has called the coalition’s commitment to a pluralistic democracy in Syria should the opposition prevail.

CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama on Wednesday nominated Caroline Kennedy to be ambassador to Japan, moving to give a scion of America’s most enduring political dynasty a diplomatic post that has often gone to political heavyweights.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: In naming Kennedy, whose appointment had been rumored for months, Obama is keeping with a long tradition of rewarding important campaign supporters with plum embassies.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: He recently nominated major fundraisers to be envoys in London and Berlin.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: But Kennedy’s value to Obama has been less about money than mystique.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: As the daughter of President John F. Kennedy, her imprimatur on his candidacy in 2008 - along with that of her uncle Sen. Edward M. Kennedy of Massachusetts - elevated him at a key moment against his better-known rival, Hillary Rodham Clinton.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: Kennedy, 55, a lawyer, author and director of numerous nonprofit organizations, has no special expertise in Japan.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: But some experts said her lack of knowledge was outweighed by her connections to the Oval Office.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: She shares that with other marquee figures who have been ambassadors to Tokyo, including former Vice President Walter F. Mondale; Howard Baker, a former senator and White House chief of staff; and Thomas S. Foley, a former speaker of the House.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: “For those who say she doesn’t know a lot about Japan, I say 'sure,' but neither did Walter Mondale,” said Kurt M. Campbell, a Japan expert who was assistant secretary of state for East Asian affairs.

column2: CAROLINE KENNEDY PICKED TO BE AMBASSADOR TO JAPAN
column3: “What you really want in an ambassador is someone who can get the president of the United States on the phone.”

RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: PHNOM PENH, Cambodia - After years of near total dominance in Cambodian politics, the party of Prime Minister Hun Sen won a relatively narrow victory in national elections Sunday as a resurgent opposition rode a wave of disenchantment with the prime minister’s 28 years in power.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: Khieu Kanharith, the Cambodian information minister, told news services that according to a preliminary count, the governing party won 68 seats, or about 55 percent of the National Assembly’s 123 seats.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: In the assembly being replaced, the governing party controlled a commanding 90 seats.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: “This is a historical day, a great day for Cambodia,” Sam Rainsy, an opposition leader who returned from exile in France nine days before the election, told a news conference.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: “People came in great numbers to express their will and democracy seemed to move forward.”

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: The opposition won 55 seats, or about 45 percent of seats in the assembly, which will make it harder for Hun Sen to impose his will.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: After years of a splintered opposition, the election signaled the arrival, permanent or not, of a de facto two-party system in Cambodia.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: The two largest opposition parties merged last year to form the Cambodia National Rescue Party.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: The opposition challenged the governing party, the Cambodian People’s Party, with a strikingly populist platform calling for a sharp rise in civil servants’ salaries, monthly payments to those more than 65 years old, and an increase in the minimum wage.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: It also included a guaranteed, government-set price for agriculture products, lower gasoline costs and free health care for the poor.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: Hun Sen’s party, as well as many analysts, questioned whether the opposition would be able to pay for all the proposed measures.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: But in a country with wide income disparities, where 40 percent of children under 5 years old are malnourished and where more than two-thirds of households lack a flush toilet, the opposition’s program resonated.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: The opposition also highlighted corruption, land seizures and concessions of wide swaths of forest given to foreign companies, especially from China and Vietnam.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: Election monitoring groups reported numerous problems with the election.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: Supposedly indelible ink to prevent people from casting votes more than once, for example, was easily removed with lime juice or bleach, observers said.

column2: RULING PARTY WINS NARROWLY IN CAMBODIAN VOTE
column3: And scores of voters were turned away because their names were not found on the list, causing minor scuffles at one Phnom Penh voting station.

column3: TAMPA

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: The Tampa couple accused of kidnapping their sons at gunpoint and absconding on a sailboat across the Gulf of Mexico tried to formally seek asylum from Cuban authorities, asserting the lives of their children were at risk from U.S. government officials, one parent’s lawyer said Monday.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: Joshua and Sharyn Hakken met with a lawyer in Cuba after arriving there in April, and were initially told they would be safe from U.S. law enforcement while their asylum application was reviewed, said Tampa lawyer Bryant Camareno, who is representing Sharyn Hakken.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: ''They sought counsel, and they actually met with a lawyer in Cuba,'' Camareno said.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: ''They felt that their kids’ lives were in danger from the (U.S.) government.''

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: He said the couple also believed that if Cuba rejected them, they would have time to seek protection at other foreign governments’ embassies in Havana.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: The couple’s dreams of a safe haven abroad were short-lived.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: Within days of the Hakkens’ arrival at Hemingway Marina outside Havana, Cuban authorities gave the U.S. permission to apprehend the family and extradite them to Florida.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: Both parents are jailed as they await trial in Hillsborough Circuit Court on charges including kidnapping and child abuse.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: But the description of the Hakkens’ overtures to Cuban officials and fears of government intrusion in their boys’ lives provides an early glimpse of their mind-set and legal strategy.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: Camareno’s remarks to the Tampa Bay Times, made after Joshua and Sharyn Hakken briefly appeared in court Monday, marked the first time the couple’s own account of their motives has emerged.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: The argument that the Hakkens were attempting to extricate their sons from a tyrannical child welfare system also promises to bring more national attention to the bizarre saga of an American family driven by mistrust of government to seek refuge in the Western Hemisphere’s last communist country.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum
column3: On April 3, according to the Hillsborough County Sheriff’s Office, Joshua Hakken, 35, kidnapped his children at gunpoint from the home of his mother-in-law, whom he bound with zip-ties.

column2: Boys' parents sought asylum

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: Regulators are using new powers to crack down on a high-speed trading firm that they contend was trying to manipulate the prices of futures contracts.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission said Monday that it had set penalties of $2.8 million on Panther Energy Trading for a practice known as “spoofing,” in which bogus orders are used to draw in other traders.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: The firm and its owner, Michael J. Coscia, were also barred from trading for a year.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: The agency said it was the first case to be brought using new rules against spoofing contained in the Dodd-Frank financial reform legislation.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: In addition, British regulators imposed their own fine of $903,176 on Coscia, while the Chicago Mercantile Exchange set a penalty of $2.1 million on Panther Energy and Coscia, who was also banned from trading on its exchanges for six months.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: A number of regulatory agencies have stepped up their scrutiny of high-speed trading firms, which are coming to dominate a growing number of financial markets.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: On Friday, the Financial Industry Regulatory Authority sent letters to 10 firms asking for information about their systems and controls.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: Panther Energy Trading, based in Red Bank, N.J., engaged in the problematic practices for two months in 2011 on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange’s electronic trading platform, according to the order filed by the futures commission.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: The order said the firm and Coscia used computer programs to place orders to buy futures contracts, hoping to give other traders the impression that the price of a contract was heading higher.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: Panther would sell contracts at that higher price before quickly canceling its buy orders, the commission said.

column2: NEW POWERS INVOKED TO CURB A HIGH-SPEED TRADING FEINT
column3: Panther used the strategy in 18 types of futures contracts, including those involving oil, natural gas and corn.

column3: “We will use the Dodd-Frank anti-disruptive practices provision against schemes like this one to protect market participants and promote market integrity, particularly in the growing world of electronic trading platforms,” the agency’s enforcement director, David Meister, said in a statement.

column3: Chilton said in a concurring statement that the violation “warrants the imposition of a much more significant trading ban to protect markets and consumers, and to act as a sufficient deterrent to other would-be wrongdoers.”

column2: headline
column3: WASHINGTON – A Mexican drug cartel member pleaded guilty in U.S. District Court here Thursday to the murder of U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement special agent Jaime Zapata of Brownsville during an ambush in Mexico.

column2: headline
column3: Julian Zapata Espinoza, 32, known as ''El Piolin’' or ''Tweety Bird,'' also pleaded guilty to the attempted murder of ICE special agent Victor Avila, according to Justice Department officials.

column2: headline
column3: ''Special agent Zapata died for his country in a senseless brutal attack, and special agent Avila was grievously wounded in the same ambush by members of the Los Zetas cartel,'' said Mythili(CQ) Raman(CQ), acting assistant U.S. attorney.

column2: headline
column3: Following the plea, the federal court unsealed documents that revealed the guilty pleas of three other defendants in the Mexico ambush who were also charged with murder, attempted murder and racketeering.

column2: headline
column3: Ruben Dario Venegas Rivera, 25 and Jose Ismael Nava Villagran, 30, pleaded guilty to murder and attempted murder.

column2: headline
column3: Francisco Carbajal Flores, 38, pleaded guilty to racketeering.

column2: headline
column3: Espinoza, Rivera and Villagran admitted to being members of a Los Zetas hit squad who participated in the Feb. 15, 2011 ambush of the special agents.

column2: headline
column3: The agents were serving as ICE agents in Mexico when they were surrounded and forced off the highway while traveling between Mexico City and Monterrey, near San Luis Potosi.

column2: headline
column3: Espinoza ordered the agents out of the vehicle.

column2: headline
column3: When the agents refused and tried to identify themselves as American diplomats from the U.S. Embassy, the hit squad members fired into the vehicle.

column2: headline
column3: The Zeta members continued to fire at the vehicle as the agents tried to escape by driving away.

column2: headline
column3: Zapata died from gunshot wounds he suffered in the attack.

column2: headline
column3: The suspects were later captured by Mexican authorities.

column2: headline
column3: Espinoza was extradited to Washington to face murder and attempted murder charges.

column2: headline
column3: Ronald Machen(CQ), the U.S. attorney for the District of Columbia, said the attack on U.S. agents demanded ''an intense, dedicated and forceful response.''

column2: headline
column3: Machen said the response served as a message to others that if you commit an act against a U.S. law enforcement agent in a foreign land, ''we will not forget, we will not falter and we will not rest until you are brought to justice.''

column2: headline
column3: The 2011 attack on the two U.S. agents in Mexico also led to the arrest and conviction on weapons violations of a Dallas-area man, Otilio Osorio, who illegally sold a replica AK-47 assault rifle that was found at the murder scene.

column2: headline
column3: The attack also prompted outrage in Congress.

column2: headline
column3: A bipartisan bill passed last year, and spearheaded by Rep. Michael McCaul, R-Austin; Rep. Henry Cuellar, D-Laredo; and Rep. Blake Farenthold, R-Corpus Christi, authorized $10 million over five years for cross-border training for U.S. and Mexican law enforcement and military.

column2: headline
column3: The bipartisan bill was named for agent Zapata, 32, who served in Laredo before he was transferred to the U.S. Department of Homeland Security investigations unit on human trafficking and smuggling in Mexico.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama defied Republican critics Thursday by nominating to a high-ranking State Department job an official involved in editing controversial talking points about the attack last year in Libya.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: Obama sent the Senate his choice of Victoria Nuland, a former spokeswoman for the State Department, as assistant secretary for European and Eurasian affairs.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: Nuland had long been in line for the position, but some had questioned whether the nomination would go forward after drafts of the talking points became public.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: Nuland suggested revisions to talking points prepared by the CIA after the terrorist attack that killed four Americans at the diplomatic post in Benghazi, Libya, on Sept. 11.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: In an email, she urged deleting mention of past warnings of terrorism in Libya because lawmakers could use that “to beat the State Department for not paying attention.”

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: Her confirmation hearings may serve to revive the furor.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: But Nuland, a career Foreign Service officer, has strong ties on both sides of the aisle, having served as deputy national security adviser to Vice President Dick Cheney and ambassador to NATO under President George W. Bush.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: Obama on Thursday also nominated Douglas E. Lute, his adviser on Afghanistan and Pakistan, to be the next ambassador to NATO, replacing Ivo Daalder, who is leaving the post this summer to become president of the Chicago Council on Global Affairs.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: A career Army officer, Lute first went to work for Bush as his Iraq and Afghanistan war coordinator and stayed on under Obama, focused specifically on Afghanistan.

column2: OBAMA DEFIES CRITICS WITH STATE DEPARTMENT CHOICE
column3: He retired as a lieutenant general in 2010, remaining in the White House as a civilian and helping shape the president’s plan to withdraw combat forces by the end of 2014.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: During the three and a half years that she was held in prison or under house arrest, Judge Lourdes Afiuni became a symbol of political persecution for many in Venezuela under President Hugo Chávez.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: On Friday, a court in Caracas, acting at the government’s request, ordered Afiuni to be set free in the latest sign of a shifting political landscape in post-Chávez Venezuela.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: Afiuni was jailed in December 2009 after issuing a court ruling that infuriated Chávez, who went on television and demanded that she be sentenced to 30 years in prison.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: For years Chávez ignored international appeals for her release, including from the American leftist intellectual Noam Chomsky.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: Chávez, a charismatic socialist, died in March, leaving a bitterly divided country.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: His handpicked successor, Nicolás Maduro, was elected by a slim margin in April and since then has confronted political turmoil and serious economic difficulties that have tested his nascent leadership skills.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: As Maduro lurches from one crisis to the next, the quality he seems to have honed most is delivering mixed messages at top volume.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: He branded President Barack Obama “the big boss of the devils” and then sent his foreign minister to shake hands with Secretary of State John Kerry and call for warmer relations.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: He assailed capitalists for causing soaring inflation and rampant product shortages and then sat down with the head of the country’s biggest private company to discuss the economy.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: “There are lots of mixed signals,” said Elsa Cardozo, a professor of political science at the Central University of Venezuela.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: “It is clear the government of President Maduro is in a situation that is forcing it to make some changes in direction.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: What we don’t know is if they are permanent changes or tactical changes.”

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: Afiuni’s release may actually be intended to counter an opposition campaign to take its message abroad, with leaders visiting countries around the world to make the case that Maduro was unfairly declared the winner of a flawed election and that his government is repressive.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: The opposition routinely points to Afiuni as the most prominent among a group of what it calls political prisoners.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: Her lawyer, José Amalio Graterol, confirmed reports last year that she was raped while in prison, became pregnant and had an abortion, which led to other health problems.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: She was moved to house arrest in Caracas in 2011.

column2: COURT IN VENEZUELA ORDERS RELEASE OF A JUDGE SCORNED BY CH Á VEZ
column3: Afiuni’s trial began in November and is continuing, although she has not attended it.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: NEW YORK - Fed up with what he views as a pattern of obstructionist behavior, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has taken the rare step of filing a lawsuit against the city comptroller, John C. Liu, for rejecting two municipal contracts.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: The contracts would pay Aguila Inc., a company run by Robert V. Hess, Bloomberg’s former commissioner of homeless services, a total of $67.6 million to operate homeless shelters in the Bronx and Manhattan.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: The Manhattan shelters have long been a target of criticism from local residents and elected officials, who say, among other complaints, that the area has an excess of similar facilities.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Liu rejected the contracts on July 3, saying they were too vague as to how many people would be offered services.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: And in a criticism of Bloomberg’s record on homelessness, Liu argued that “it would be unconscionable to compound past errors with these faulty contracts.”

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: But Bloomberg, in a lawsuit filed Thursday in state Supreme Court in Manhattan, said the courts had long held that registration of contracts was “not a vehicle for the comptroller to usurp the mayor’s authority to enter into contracts.”

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: The lawsuit, believed to be only the second filed by the Bloomberg administration against the city or state comptroller’s office, is the latest and perhaps most pronounced skirmish between Bloomberg and Liu, a Democrat who is now running for mayor.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Administration officials contend that there is a discrepancy between the reasons Liu cites in his news releases for rejecting a contract and the public documents explaining the reasons.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Liu, the city contends, typically asks for more technical information, then registers those contracts with few if any changes and no public notification.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “It’s a joke,” Marc La Vorgna, Bloomberg’s press secretary, said of Liu.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “Sad part is this is taxpayer resources and dollars being completely wasted on naked political ambitions.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: He was running for mayor the second he stepped into this job and had no interest in doing the job he was sworn in to do, only to abuse the position.”

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Aides to Liu argue that the comptroller needs to highlight certain Bloomberg proposals because the mayor has mishandled contracts, like those for the CityTime payroll project and for an overhaul of the 911 system.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “Under Mayor Bloomberg, spending on outside contractors has ballooned, and his outsourcing philosophy is out of control,” said Stephanie Hoo, a spokeswoman for the comptroller.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “In all cases, whenever this office has questioned contracts, it has been within the guidelines of the City Charter and our mandate to protect taxpayers from wasteful spending.”

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: In the rare cases where a mayor or a comptroller sues the other over contracts, the courts have held that comptrollers have extremely limited powers.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: In 2006, the Court of Appeals rejected former Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr.'s effort to void a contract on Snapple, writing that “the Charter establishes in plain language that the mayor and the corporation counsel - not the comptroller - bear the burden of determining that procedural requirements have been met and legal authority exists to award a concession contract.” (Thompson ran against Bloomberg in 2009 and is again seeking the Democratic nomination for mayor.)

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Under the charter, the only basis for a comptroller to scuttle a contract is evidence of possible corruption in the contracting process.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: In rejecting the shelter contracts, Liu mentioned not corruption, but concerns over inspections and certificates of occupancy.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Bloomberg administration officials cited more than a half-dozen instances in recent years in which Liu publicized a rejection of a contract, then quietly registered it.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: In March 2011, for example, Liu rejected a $20 million deal on teacher recruitment, saying the timing was “curious at best” because of Bloomberg’s threat to fire teachers.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: But the reasons for rejecting the contract pertained to data input and an incomplete insurance certificate.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: Liu registered the contract that July, with minimal changes.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: When asked about the discrepancies between press statements and public documents, Hoo did not directly address the issue, but rather alluded to the mayor’s maneuver to run for a third term in 2009.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “It is beyond ironic that Mayor Bloomberg’s Law Department is up in arms about adherence to the City Charter when no one in the history of New York City has shown such deep disrespect for the City Charter,” she said.

column2: NEW YORK MAYOR SUES COMPTROLLER ON CONTRACTS
column3: “If we’d followed the charter, he wouldn’t even be in office right now.”

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: WASHINGTON - President Barack Obama plans to nominate James B. Comey, a former hedge fund executive and a former senior Justice Department official under President George W. Bush, to replace Robert S. Mueller III as the director of the FBI, according to a person with knowledge of the selection.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: Comey, 52, was chosen for the position over the other finalist for the job, Lisa O. Monaco, who has served as the White House’s top counterterrorism adviser since January.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: Some Democrats had feared that if the president nominated Monaco - who oversaw national security issues at the Justice Department during the attacks in Benghazi, Libya, in September - Republicans would use the confirmation process as a forum for criticism of the administration’s handling of the attack.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: As deputy attorney general in the Bush administration, Comey was a critical player in 2004 in the dramatic hospital room episode in which the White House counsel, Alberto Gonzales, and Bush’s chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., tried to persuade Attorney General John Ashcroft - who was ill and disoriented - to reauthorize a warrantless eavesdropping program.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: Comey, who was serving as the acting attorney general and had been tipped off that Gonzales and Card were trying to go around him, rushed to Ashcroft’s hospital room to thwart them.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: With Comey in the room, Ashcroft refused to reauthorize the program.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: After the episode, Bush agreed to make changes in the program, and Comey was widely praised for putting the law over politics.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: Comey graduated from the University of Chicago Law School in 1985, then had a meteoric rise at the Justice Department, culminating in his service as the department’s second-ranking official from 2003 to 2005.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: While oversee the U.S. attorney’s office in Richmond, Va., Comey was asked in 2001 to take over the government’s foundering investigation of the 1996 terrorist bombing at Khobar Towers in Saudi Arabia that killed 19 American service members.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: The FBI director at the time, Louis J. Freeh, had urged Ashcroft to take the case away from federal prosecutors in Washington who had been investigating for five years but had not brought charges.

column2: OBAMA TO PICK FORMER BUSH JUSTICE DEPT. OFFICIAL TO LEAD FBI
column3: With a legal deadline looming over them, Comey and a colleague rapidly moved the case forward and within three months indicted 14 men.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: PALM SPRINGS, Calif. - President Barack Obama and China’s new president, Xi Jinping, arrived at a famed desert estate here Friday evening for their unusually informal weekend meeting, starting with discussions of security issues that bedevil them, including North Korea’s nuclear threat, on which the United States sees a chance at greater cooperation.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: On Saturday, officials said, the leaders plan to delve into economic issues, including the United States’ accusation that Beijing has encouraged or at least tolerated cyberattacks on U.S. systems in which business and military secrets were stolen.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: On a day when the temperature here reached 110 degrees, Obama and Xi, along with their interpreters and closest aides, retreated to the comfort of the sprawling Sunnylands estate in nearby Rancho Mirage, built by the publishing magnate Walter H. Annenberg.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: On the question of tensions with North Korea, inflamed this year by a series of belligerent statements and actions from its young leader, Kim Jong Un, the administration has welcomed what officials have described as a growing impatience in China - on the part of Xi in particular - with its longstanding ally in Pyongyang.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: That has raised administration hopes of new cooperation.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: China voted with the rest of the U.N. Security Council to impose new sanctions on North Korea after it tested a nuclear device in February.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: And when a close adviser to Kim visited China last month, Xi bluntly told him that North Korea should resume international negotiations intended to force it to abandon its nuclear arsenal.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: Xi also appears to have invested heavily in the meetings here with Obama.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: Xi, who took office in March, told Obama’s departing national security adviser, Tom Donilon, who arranged the meetings, that the relationship between the United States and China had reached a critical juncture and that he wanted to develop “a new type of great power relationship.”

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: China also offered its own gestures in advance of the Sunnylands summit meeting on one of the prickliest issues with the United States: its treatment of human rights.

column2: OBAMA AND CHINESE PRESIDENT OPEN INFORMAL MEETINGS IN CALIFORNIA
column3: On Friday, only hours before the two leaders met, China granted passports to the mother and brother of Chen Guangcheng, the blind lawyer and activist whose flight from China last year turned into a diplomatic drama between the two countries.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: Regulators are taking a closer look at whether high-frequency trading firms might represent a threat to the stability of financial markets.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority, an industry-financed regulator, sent letters to 10 high-speed trading firms this week, asking them for more information about their trading programs and the steps they have in place to avert “market disruptions.”

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: The letter comes as regulators around the world are grappling with the role that high-speed trading firms have come to play over the last decade as they have grown to account for a majority of all trading in U.S. stocks.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: These firms, which use high-speed computers and infrastructure to take advantage of small discrepancies in trading prices, have also taken an increasing role in trading in other markets.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: The letter sent out this week is focused primarily on the steps the firms take to test their programs, or algorithms, before they begin trading with them, and the preparations they take to deal with unexpected trading problems.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: Regulators have been focused on these issues since one trading firm, Knight Capital, lost nearly $500 million and nearly went bankrupt after its trading programs went haywire last August.

column2: FINRA SCRUTINIZES HIGH-SPEED TRADING FIRMS
column3: The letter also asks about efforts to monitor market “manipulation.” Earlier this year, FINRA said in an annual report that it was concerned about high-speed trading strategies that are “used for manipulative purposes.”

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: The administrator, Malik Taylor, 31, had sexual intercourse with students who ranged in age from 16 to 19, and also sexually harassed four other students while he worked as a community assistant and a dean at the high school, the Business of Sports School in Midtown, according to a report by the special commissioner of investigation for the city’s schools.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: In an interview with investigators in June, Taylor admitted that he had had unprotected sex with students in motel rooms, in the back of his car and in classrooms after school.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: He made lewd comments about the size of students’ buttocks and breasts, and sent inappropriate text messages from a cellphone assigned to his wife, the report stated.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: He also asked one of the students to buy marijuana for him, it said.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: Taylor emailed his resignation to the school’s principal, Joshua Solomon, in May, after one of the students told him that she had reported him.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: That student told a teacher that she was having a sexual relationship with Taylor, and that she knew of others who were as well.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: The teacher then told the school’s assistant principal, Rosa Choi, who notified the special commissioner’s office.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: The city has referred the report to the district attorneys in Manhattan and Brooklyn for further action.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: Attempts on Tuesday evening to reach Taylor, Choi and Solomon by phone and email were unsuccessful.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: On Tuesday, the city’s Education Department said that Taylor’s actions were “completely reprehensible” and that he had been barred from teaching in the city.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: Taylor worked at the school for about a year, and his salary was $32,000.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: One relationship started when a student came to Taylor to discuss personal problems, the report said.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: It stated that Taylor began talking to her in a sexual way, and then told her he wanted her to have his child.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: He and another student exchanged about 6,000 text messages during a three-month period, the investigation showed.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: That student said Taylor groped her in the school cafeteria and made inappropriate comments to her.

column2: HIGH SCHOOL OFFICIAL HAD SEX WITH FOUR STUDENTS, CITY SAYS
column3: She eventually agreed to have sex with him at a motel after he asked her for months to be intimate with him, according to the report.

column2: KILLER OF TWO UNDERCOVER DETECTIVES IS SENT BACK TO DEATH ROW
KILLER OF TWO UNDERCOVER DETECTIVES IS SENT BACK TO DEATH ROW
column3: NEW YORK - Ronell Wilson, whose first death sentence for killing two undercover police detectives was overturned, was sentenced again Wednesday to die by a federal jury that heard gripping testimony about his time in jail, where he roamed freely after the shootings, intimidated fellow inmates and fathered a child with a guard.

column2: KILLER OF TWO UNDERCOVER DETECTIVES IS SENT BACK TO DEATH ROW
column3: The anonymous jury took just five hours to reach its decision to return Wilson to federal death row, where no other New Yorker has served time in six decades.

column2: KILLER OF TWO UNDERCOVER DETECTIVES IS SENT BACK TO DEATH ROW
column3: As the jury foreman responded to preliminary questions, Wilson, 31, slumped forward with his chin in his hands as the tension rose in the courtroom in U.S. District Court in Brooklyn.

column2: KILLER OF TWO UNDERCOVER DETECTIVES IS SENT BACK TO DEATH ROW

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: by Steve Bousquet,

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Times Columnist

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Rick Scott is the first governor in the history of Florida (and likely the last) to travel the state in his own personal jet.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: He’s a one-man airline.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Air Scott.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: As a candidate in 2010, Scott thought it was extravagant for taxpayers to pay for two state aircraft to transport politicians in the nation’s fourth-largest state.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Elect me, Scott promised, and I’ll get rid of those expensive toys.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: He got elected and ditched both planes, which would have been impossible if Scott wasn’t rich enough to travel in style on his own nickel.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Selling the planes grounded other state officials, who must travel by car or fly on the rare scheduled commercial flights out of Tallahassee, which is often impractical.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: In today’s Florida, the only elected official who gets to fly is the one who can afford it.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Everywhere Scott goes, he does it on his own aircraft at his own expense, and after nearly two-and-a-half years in office, he has decided he needs an upgrade.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Scott is selling his eight-passenger Hawker 400XP, made by Raytheon in 2004, for $1.495 million.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: An ad for the jet on the website controller.com says the jet is in Bonita Springs and notes: ''Price reduction!

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Sale pending.''

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Scott’s new chariot is a 2008 Cessna Citation Excel, a 12-passenger twin-engine jet with a dropped aisle that offers enough headroom for Scott to stand tall in the cabin.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: The Cessna is white with pink trim and the plane’s tail number ends with the letters ''AS,'' which can only stand for first lady Ann Scott (the old plane’s tail number ended with ''RS’').

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: The new plane, like the old one, is registered to a Naples holding company, Columbia Collier Properties, whose signatory on legal documents is Ann Scott.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: The purchase price of the new plane was not immediately available, and it’s not the kind of information the governor’s office would willingly provide.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: ''The governor wants to travel the state as often as possible to listen to the concerns and ideas of Floridians,'' said Scott’s chief spokeswoman, Melissa Sellers.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Scott travels more often than his predecessor and possible future rival, Charlie Crist, who traveled at taxpayers’ expense.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: In fact, the Republican Party of Florida, as part of a series critically examining Crist’s record, noted that Monday was the fourth anniversary of a Times/Herald story that cited his use of state aircraft to attract publicity at ceremonial bill-signing events while campaigning for the U.S. Senate.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: By paying for all of his flight costs, Scott has saved taxpayers a bundle, but exactly how much is a mystery.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: The governor’s office says it has no records reflecting the costs to operate and maintain his own plane.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Also not known is how much of a tax benefit Scott derives by using his jet for business purposes.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: Scott doesn’t take a government salary, either.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime
column3: He is paid a penny a month, or 12 cents a year, which the state says is the minimum necessary for him to be registered in the state personnel system.

column2: Scott travels state in new jet, still on his own dime

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: IN the five years since the last farm bill was passed, the number of farmers' markets in this country has grown to nearly 4,500 from 2,750, gladdening the hearts of foodies who like nothing better than seeing locally grown Chioggia beets, butter radishes, Early Girl tomatoes, miniature pattypan squash, chervil, fresh goat cheese logs and duck breast in a conveniently located market.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Some of the best customers of farmers' markets, though, haven't been free-spending foodies, but food-aid recipients.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Happily, the new farm bill before Congress has several proposals to vastly increase food aid to the poor, including two programs that allow them to buy at farmers' markets.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: That normally would be great for small farmers.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Without the guaranteed income from the farm bill's $15 million Seniors Farmers' Market Nutrition Program and the separate $25 million Farmers' Market Nutrition Program (part of the food aid program for families known as WIC), some small growers would be out of business, and many others would be reluctant to sell in low-income neighborhoods where fresh produce is otherwise a rarity -- ''food deserts.''

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: But, it turns out, new efforts to encourage food-aid recipients to eat more fruits and vegetables -- which are calamitously underrepresented in American diets -- could end up shutting out the small farmers who are the backbone of these markets.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: The Agriculture Department has proposed rules that would reallocate WIC benefits now restricted to eggs and dairy products, which have long enjoyed the muscle of well-financed lobbies, to fruits and vegetables, which haven't.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Millions of children would be entitled to $6 a month for produce.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: And in its initial proposals for the new farm bill, the Bush administration suggested making available $200 million, starting next year, to buy fruits and vegetables for the poor.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: If such suggestions get approved, hundreds of millions more dollars could be spent every year on fresh produce.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: There's a big catch, though: small farmers might not reap the windfall.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Over the past 15 years, most states have switched from paper coupons for food stamps to debit cards, removing the stigma of redemption at the checkout counter.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: Most farmers, of course, don't take plastic -- and, market managers say, they have seen their sales plummet with the switch from paper.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market
column3: The need for farmers to enter the cashless economy is obvious.

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market

column2: Less Green at the Farmers’ Market

column3: NEW YORK, Dec. 3 (Xinhua) -- Qatar's announcement Monday to withdraw from the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) sparked investors' concerns over a more volatile policy-making in the global oil market, amid persistent fears of oversupply and shrinking demand shown in constant price slides over the last two months.

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua
column3: "The high volatility and large down move of the last 60 days will have a lasting impact on trading going into first quarter of 2019," said Albert Helmig, CEO of Grey House, a private consulting firm focused on market structure, risk management and price models.

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua
column3: CONCERNS BUILD UP

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua
column3: Qatar's decision to end its 57-year membership in the oil cartel on Jan. 1, 2019 came three days ahead of a meeting between the Saudi-led OPEC and its allies to reshape global oil policy to grapple with broad price drops.

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Analysis: Qatar's OPEC exit raises concerns over global oil policy-making - Xinhua

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
