column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: As per the fourth advance estimates (released in August) for the year 2017-2018, total food grains production in the country was estimated at 284.83 million tons which was higher by 9.72 million tons than the previous record production of foodgrain of 275.11 million tons achieved during 2016-2017.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: However, despite all this rosy picture, farmers in India are a dejected lot these days, and are venting out their anger against the government's policies, which they allege, overlook their interests and basic needs.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Barely able to recover their basic costs, the farmers allege that agriculture is fast turning into an unfeasible activity.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Fed up after not being able to sell his onion produce of around 750 kg at a price more than 1.41 Indian Rupees (around 2 cents) per kg, a farmer in India's southwestern state Maharashtra sent whatever money he could receive by selling his total produce to Prime Minister Narendra Modi through a money order as a mark of protest and to highlight the farmers' plight.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Sanjay Sathe, the farmer from Maharashtra's Nasik district, reportedly said, "I produced 750 kg of onion this season but was offered a rate of one Indian rupee per kilogram at Niphad wholesale market last week.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Finally I could negotiate a deal for 1.40 Indian rupees per kilogram and received 1,064 Indian rupees for 750 kg.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: It was painful to see such paltry returns on four months of toil.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Hence I have donated 1,064 Indian Rupees to Prime Minister Disaster Relief Fund as a protest.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: I had to pay additional 54 Indian rupees for sending it by money order."

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Interestingly, Sathe was among the selected few "progressive farmers" who were picked by the Union Agriculture Ministry in 2010 to interact with former U.S. President Barack Obama during the latter's visit.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Strangely, while on one hand, the farmers are not able to recover their bare minimum cost, on the other hand, the retailers are openly selling the same commodity at least 20 times the cost which is paid to the farmers, thereby reaping heavy profits.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Sribhagwan Singh, a farmer in Kanganheri village located in southwest Delhi, laments that he grew garlic on his farms and reaped a harvest of around 800 kg, but is not able to sell it in the market as he is getting a price of not more than 10 Indian rupees per kg.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: "The bare minimum cost which I incurred in growing this garlic produce was at least 25 Indian rupees per kilogram.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: For over the past three months I have been contacting vendors in big vegetable markets in and around Delhi, but not able to find a buyer of my produce for more than 10 Indian rupees per kilogram.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The final conclusion is that farming is a loss making entity in India, and farmers have no option but to quit it and look for some alternative source of income," he told Xinhua.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: He added that the same garlic was being sold in retail market in Delhi and surrounding areas at the rate of 150 Indian rupees per kg.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Only a few days ago, thousands of farmers congregated in Delhi from across the country and carried out a two-day agitation against the central government, demanding loan waivers and increase in minimum support prices (MSPs) for their agriculture produce.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Due to big amounts of loans standing in their names and finding no possibilities of getting a stable income from agriculture, the farmers are driven to a situation where they find no alternative but to commit suicides.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Farmers suicides has a major cause of concern in India for many years now, with the state of Maharashtra being on top.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The country's Agriculture Minister Radha Mohan Singh, however, claims that the number of farmers suicides in on the decline.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: A couple of months ago he informed the parliament that the number of farmers suicides and agricultural laborers during 2016 had come down approximately by 9.77 percent compared to the previous years.

column3: "The number of suicides has come down from 12,602 in 2015 to 11,370 in 2016," he was quoted as saying.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The maximum number of these suicides were reported from the state of Maharashtra.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The main reasons behind agriculture being a loss making activity in India is the large dependence on monsoons and lack of use of modern farming techniques.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Due to non-availability of water resources round the year, a large chunk of farmers depend on monsoon rains.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: At times, due to poor rains, or floods caused by excess rains, standing crops get damaged thereby resulting in huge losses to the farmers.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Besides, use of traditional farming methods and non-acceptance of modern equipment and techniques, also results in poor produce in terms of yield per hectare, as compared to other countries.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: In a bid to address the farmers' woes, Prime Minister Narendra Modi has announced that a new agriculture export policy will be unveiled soon to boost farm income as the government was on track to achieve the target of doubling farmers' income by 2022.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The main thrust of the policy would be fixing the minimum support price (MSP) of crops at least 1.5 times of the cost of production.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: The Crop Insurance Schemes have been in place as a means of protecting the agriculturist against financial losses due to uncertainties that may arise from crop failures or losses arising from named or all unforeseen perils beyond their control.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: One such scheme - Pradhan Mantri Fasal Bima Yojana (PMFBY) (or, Prime Minister Crop Insurance Scheme) aims at supporting sustainable production in agriculture sector by way of providing financial support to farmers suffering crop loss/damage arising out of unforeseen events; stabilizing their income to ensure their continuance in farming; encouraging farmers to adopt innovative and modern agricultural practices; ensuring flow of credit to the agriculture sector which will contribute to food security, crop diversification and enhancing growth and competitiveness of agriculture sector besides protecting farmers from production risks.

column2: Spotlight: Indian farmers await gov't policies to yield rosy results - Xinhua
column3: Amidst all this, the farmers community in India continues to live in abject poverty in the hope of seeing the government's polices yielding results on the ground on fine day.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: COPENHAGEN (Reuters) - Orsted (ORSTED.CO), the world’s largest offshore wind developer, said on Monday it would buy U.S.-based Deepwater Wind LLC for $510 million as part of its strategy to expand in a major growth market.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: The still small U.S. offshore wind sector is seen as one of the most important markets outside the core European region, where subsidies that have underpinned the industry since the early 1990s are starting to be wound back.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: Deepwater Wind, the builder of the only operating U.S. offshore wind farm, has a portfolio with a capacity of around 3.3 gigawatts (GW).

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: Orsted’s U.S portfolio currently has a capacity of 5.5 GW.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: Orsted has so far lost out on auctions in the nascent market, while Deepwater Wind has been more successful and currently has the right to develop wind farms in Rhode Island, New York and Connecticut.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: “With this transaction we’re creating the number one offshore wind platform in North America,” Orsted’s offshore wind chief Martin Neubert in a statement.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: The drive to open America’s offshore wind industry has attracted Europe’s biggest renewable energy companies, who see the U.S. East Coast as a new frontier after years of success across the Atlantic.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: Orsted said the acquisition increased its capital expenditure guidance to 23-25 billion Danish crowns ($3.55-3.86 billion) this year from previous guidance of 16-18 billion.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: The new guidance includes the acquisition price of Deepwater Wind, early capex commitments for the U.S. business in the fourth quarter, “as well as increased spending in the remaining portfolio due to timing”.

column2: Offshore wind firm Orsted expands U.S. business with $510 million acquisition
column3: Orsted also recently acquired U.S. onshore wind developer Lincoln Clean Energy.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: QUITO, Dec. 10 (Xinhua) -- Ecuadorian President Lenin Moreno's state visit to China will strengthen the comprehensive strategic partnership between the two countries, Chinese Ambassador to Ecuador Wang Yulin said.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: In a recent interview with Xinhua, Wang held Ecuador as "a very important partner ... for pragmatic cooperation in the region," highlighting the comprehensive strategic partnership between the two countries.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: The visit, scheduled for Tuesday to Thursday, will actively improve bilateral cooperation to yield "growth, maturity and shared gains in the process of cooperation," Wang told Xinhua in a recent interview.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: The trip will mark Moreno's first visit to China since he took office on May 24, 2017.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: The two countries raised ties to the level of a comprehensive strategic partnership in November 2016, during Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Ecuador, the first by a Chinese head of state to the South American country since the two nations established diplomatic ties in 1980.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Wang said he has witnessed numerous "memorable historic moments" in bilateral ties in the past three years as ambassador.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Pragmatic cooperation between China and Ecuador in diverse areas has a "broad future," said Wang.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Bilateral ties "have quickly progressed," especially following Xi's visit, and "are at a historic peak," the ambassador said.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: The two countries are stepping up exchange in a range of areas, from trade and economy to politics, science and technology, as well as culture and education, he added.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: China responded rapidly and effectively when Ecuador was hit by a devastating 7.8-magnitude earthquake that ravaged communities along the country's northern coast on April 16, 2016, leaving 673 people dead and extensive structural damage.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: "The Chinese government and people felt empathy for the Ecuadorian government and people suffering from the disaster, and offered timely aid," said Wang.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: "Close friendship shortens distances."

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Despite being separated by vast oceans, China and Ecuador "have become good friends with sincerity and mutual trust, and good partners in mutually beneficial cooperation," said the ambassador.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: He said the two countries have collaborated closely and supported one another in international and regional affairs.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Ecuador "has not only been a strategic partner in energy (cooperation), a target country for Chinese financing and investment, and a market for infrastructure works, but also a trade partner with great potential in Latin America," said Wang.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: He noted that China is now Ecuador's second-largest trade partner after the United States, with bilateral exchange amounting to 4.62 billion U.S. dollars during the first 10 months of 2018, which marks a year-on-year increase of 36.6 percent.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: "More and more Ecuadorian bananas and shrimp are served at Chinese tables, and Ecuadorian roses are well-liked by Chinese consumers," said Wang.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Currently, more than 90 Chinese companies are operating in Ecuador in sectors including energy, mining, construction and infrastructure.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Wang highlighted that many projects involving Chinese companies have become emblems of the strategic bilateral cooperation, leading to tangible benefits for the Ecuadorian people.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: In January, at the second ministerial meeting of the China-CELAC (Community of Latin American and Caribbean States) Forum held in Santiago, Chile, Ecuador expressed an interest in participating in the China-proposed Belt and Road Initiative to boost global trade and infrastructure, the diplomat said.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: Despite the geographic distance, there is "great potential and a positive outlook in bilateral cooperation in all fields," said Wang.

column2: Interview: Ecuadorian president's visit to strengthen bilateral ties, says Chinese ambassador - Xinhua
column3: "Those who unite behind same ideals can overcome all physical distance."

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: BUENOS AIRES/SAO PAULO (Reuters) - Uber’s fastest-growing market in the world is now Argentina, company executives say, attributing the expansion to the nation’s sudden economic unraveling, which has boosted unemployment and sliced the purchasing power of Argentines.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Twenty percent of its drivers in Buenos Aires, the only city where it operates in Argentina, were jobless immediately before joining Uber.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: The economic downturn, “has certainly helped many people find us as an alternative source of income,” Felipe Fernandez Aramburu, who runs Uber business development in Argentina, told Reuters in a recent interview.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Despite worries about the country’s economy, which shrank 4.2 percent in the second quarter after its central bank hiked rates to ward off a currency crisis, the company says it does not fear that a recession could boost the number of drivers without an equivalent increase in demand.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “Our growth today is less about economic conditions on the rider side,” said Andrew Macdonald, who runs Uber in Latin America.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Instead, Macdonald expects what he described as a paucity of public transportation options to lift demand in Argentina and said growth was highest in the neighborhoods with the least bus and train service.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: But Uber’s Argentine unit still faces a snag: For most rides, the company does not charge its drivers the 25 percent commission it is theoretically owed.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Due to legal and regulatory hurdles, Uber rides in Argentina can only be paid with cash or credit cards issued abroad, which almost no locals have.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: When rides are paid in cash, drivers currently have no way to pay Uber its 25 percent commission, leaving many with a growing debt to the company.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Commissions from drivers are Uber’s only source of revenue.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Uber’s Argentine conundrum of being unable to profit from its fast growth there mirrors a wider problem for the ride hailing service, which has struggled to prove that it can be profitable as it gears up for a planned 2019 initial public offering.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: ‘TOO MANY DRIVERS’

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Macdonald played down those concerns, however.

column3: Uber driver Juan Carlos, who wished not to give his last name, uses his application map on his cellphone as he drives his car in Buenos Aires, Argentina September 19, 2018.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Picture taken September 19, 2018.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: REUTERS/Marcos Brindicci

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “It’s not about whether we are making money in the near term,” he said, adding that the company will “eventually” have to charge those commissions.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Macdonald would not say whether the Argentine market is profitable.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Uber has disclosed that its operations in nearby Brazil - now the company’s second-biggest market worldwide - are profitable.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Once Uber can accept local credit and debit cards, it will be able to recoup what it is owed, the company said.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Drivers, however, say the current Argentine growth rate may be temporary, tied to the lack of a commission charge.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “What’s going on is that there are too many drivers currently and so there’s less work for us,” said Jorge, a 62-year old Uber driver who requested anonymity.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “Everyone’s coming to Uber because they don’t charge a commission.”

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Uber says that in the last three months, it has had 55,000 active drivers and 1 million active users in Buenos Aires.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Each day, the company said it adds between 300 and 400 new drivers and 7,000 new users.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: There’s also attrition in the mix.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “The average lifespan for a driver in Latin America is about three to four months.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: It means they use Uber as something temporary,” Fernandez Aramburu said.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Uber’s recruitment success reflects a wider trend within Argentina, where a rising jobless rate has hit full-time jobs with benefits in particular, economists say.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “We are going through a process that is making labor rights more precarious, and formal employment is dwindling,” said Hernan Letcher, director of the Center for Argentine Economic Policy.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Uber has been operating in Argentina since 2016, when it faced aggressive resistance from taxi drivers and government authorities, including legal disputes that led to the ban on credit card payments that is still in place.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: There is no regulatory framework for Uber in Buenos Aires, including no way for the government to collect sales tax on the rides.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: Macdonald said the company welcomes favorable regulation and that accepting local credit cards is a priority, which will make more drivers pay their 25 percent commission but could also increase Uber’s business.

column2: Uber's strongest growth comes in depressed Argentina -- minus commissions
column3: “It’s a testament to our investment in Argentina ... that we are able to grow so much even without being able to offer the convenience of all payment options,” Macdonald said.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: (Reuters) - Campbell Soup Co’s (CPB.N) board is drawing up a list of CEO candidates, with Chief Operating Officer Luca Mignini emerging as the top internal contender, as the company seeks to fend off a proxy challenge from Daniel Loeb’s hedge fund, Third Point LLC, people familiar with the matter said.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: FILE PHOTO: Tins of Campbell's tomato soup are seen on a supermarket shelf in Seattle, Washington, U.S. February 10, 2017.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Third Point unveiled a slate of nominees on Friday to replace Campbell’s 12-member board, pushing it to more actively explore a sale and criticizing its lack of a succession plan after Chief Executive Denise Morrison left in May.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Morrison’s departure came after several years of weak corporate earnings.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Campbell board member Keith McLoughlin, who has served as interim CEO since Morrison’s departure, has said he is not interested in the job on a permanent basis.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: That has added to pressure on Campbell to find a leader who will help it execute an ambitious turnaround plan it unveiled last month.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Despite Morrison’s exit almost four months ago, the board has only recently taken formal steps to look externally for a new CEO, according to the sources.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Mignini, 55, joined Campbell five years ago and was promoted in April to be its COO, putting the Italian-educated executive in charge of the U.S. company’s snack and meal businesses, in addition to U.S. sales and global development.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Morrison also held the COO position before she took the top job in 2011.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Investors who met with McLoughlin and Campbell Chief Financial Officer Anthony DiSilvestro in recent days told Reuters that Mignini joined the meetings, in a sign the company was seeking to raise his profile.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Mignini did not usually attend such meetings in the past, the investors said.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: CNBC reported in May, at the time of Morrison’s departure, that Mignini was a likely candidate for the CEO seat.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: The board is also preparing to interview candidates from outside the company, although nobody external has been contacted yet, according to one of the people familiar with the arrangements.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Campbell’s board, which includes three heirs of John Dorrance, the chemist who invented condensed soup and ran the company nearly a century ago, will review a list of external candidates at its next meeting at the end of September, the source added.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: The sources asked not to be identified because the deliberations are confidential.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: A Campbell spokesman declined to comment on whether Mignini was the top internal candidate and said the board had been working with executive-search firms to assess both internal and external candidates.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Third Point declined to comment.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Campbell Soup shares were up 0.5 percent at $40.40 in early morning trading on Monday, giving the company a market capitalization of about $12 billion.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Third Point’s board challenge could complicate the CEO selection process, given that shareholders could choose to replace board members who will be making that decision, in a vote that could be scheduled as early as November.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: The turmoil could discourage some of the consumer industry’s top executives from applying, the sources said.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Third Point faces an uphill struggle in any battle for control of Campbell Soup, given that descendants of Dorrance own a combined stake of about 42 percent in the company.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: A board challenge could ratchet up pressure on Campbell, however, to explore a sale with more urgency.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: EXTERNAL CANDIDATES

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Third Point, which manages $18 billion in assets, has played a role in bringing new CEOs to several companies, including Jose Almeida to Baxter International Inc (BAX.N), Tad Smith to Sotheby’s (BID.N), and Marissa Mayer to Yahoo.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: One external CEO candidate Campbell Soup’s board is expected to consider is Mark Clouse, chief executive of Pinnacle Foods Inc PF.N, who will soon be without a full-time job after his company agreed in June to sell itself to ConAgra Brands Inc (CAG.N) for $8.1 billion.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Clouse, 49, is an industry veteran, having also held senior positions at Oreo-maker Mondelez International Inc (MDLZ.O) and Kraft Foods Inc.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: It is not clear if Clouse would be interested.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: He could not be reached for comment.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Campbell said on Aug. 30 it planned to sell its international and fresh refrigerated-foods units, and only left open the possibility of putting the whole company up for sale in the future, snubbing a call from Third Point to do so urgently.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: The 149-year-old company, which revolutionized the home-cooking industry with easy-to-prepare soups and low-cost production techniques, has been struggling to attract young consumers to its namesake soups and Pepperidge Farm cookies.

column2: Exclusive: Campbell Soup steps up CEO search, COO a contender - sources
column3: Campbell’s latest foray into fresh food has faltered, while Wall Street has questioned an acquisition strategy that increased debt at the same time as costs increased.

column2: Singapore's CPI growth falls to 0.3 pct in November - Xinhua
column3: The MAS Core Inflation, which excludes the costs of accommodation and private road transport, declined from 1.9 percent on a year-on-year basis in October to 1.7 percent in November.

column2: Singapore's CPI growth falls to 0.3 pct in November - Xinhua
column3: The authorities said the CPI decline was largely due to a sharper fall in private road transport costs, and to a lesser extent, smaller increases in the prices of services, retail items and electricity and gas, which more than offset a slower pace of decline in accommodation costs.

column2: Singapore's CPI growth falls to 0.3 pct in November - Xinhua
column3: As for the MAS Core Inflation, they attributed the decline to a smaller increases in the costs of services, retail items and electricity and gas.

column2: Singapore's CPI growth falls to 0.3 pct in November - Xinhua
column3: The MTI and MAS reiterated their forecasts, saying the city-state will see the MAS Core Inflation rise modestly in the months ahead, and come in within the forecast range of 1.5-2 percent in 2018 and 1.5-2.5 percent in 2019.

column2: Singapore's CPI growth falls to 0.3 pct in November - Xinhua
column3: The CPI is projected to grow by about 0.5 percent in 2018, before rising to 1-2 percent in 2019, they added.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: A public pension fund in Louisiana has sued the directors of Caremark Rx, contending that their unanimous backing of the company's $21 billion merger with CVS over a rival $26 billion bid from Express Scripts improperly benefits Caremark executives at the expense of shareholders.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Among the benefits Caremark executives and directors will receive if the CVS deal goes through, the fund's lawsuit contends, are positions at the combined company and indemnification from penalties and fines that may result when criminal and regulatory investigations into possible stock option backdating by Caremark officials are concluded.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Yesterday, Express Scripts filed suit to block the CVS deal, arguing that the terms deal supported by the Caremark board prevents its directors from executing their fiduciary duties to shareholders.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The lawsuits, filed in Delaware Chancery Court, will once again bring the fiduciary duties of directors in the post-Enron world to the forefront.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Delaware is where most major United States companies are incorporated.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Caremark accepted the CVS bid on Nov. 1, even though the stock-for-stock deal offered no premium to Caremark's market price at the time.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Caremark's directors have recommended that company shareholders approve the deal at a meeting that is expected to occur before March 16.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: On Monday, Caremark rejected the $26 billion bid made on Dec. 18 by Express Scripts, saying that it would ''result in a highly leveraged and weakened business'' if it was approved by shareholders.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The Express Scripts offer of $58.50 a share is approximately 15 percent higher than the CVS bid.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The lawsuit filed by the Louisiana Municipal Police Employees' Retirement System contends that the CVS deal is unfair to Caremark shareholders not only because its price is significantly below the rival bid.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The pension fund's lawyers also argue that Caremark directors improperly accepted deal protection provisions in the CVS bid that act to deter other bidders, effectively making the deal a fait accompli even before the shareholders vote.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: First, there is the $675 million breakup fee to be paid by Caremark in cash to CVS, if the target walks away.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Then, there is a so-called last-look provision, which gives CVS the chance to come back and top any rival bid.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: ''Any potential third-party bidders will be loath to invest the time and resources necessary to pursue a superior bid while knowing full well that CVS retains control of the bidding,'' the pension fund's lawsuit says.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The Louisiana fund accuses the Caremark board of supporting the deal to benefit Edwin M. Crawford, the company's chief executive, and other executives.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Under the terms of the deal, nine Caremark executives will join the combined company and Mr. Crawford will become chairman of its board and receive an estimated $48 million in exit pay.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: While he would probably receive a similar amount if Caremark sold out to Express Scripts, Mr. Crawford might not be asked to join the combined company under the terms of such a deal.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The Louisiana pension fund also noted that the CVS deal guarantees a job at the merged company for Mr. Crawford's son, Andrew.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: A Caremark proxy filed last year described the younger Mr. Crawford as senior vice president for industry analysis and underwriting.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: The merger with CVS would also allow an unspecified number of Caremark directors -- perhaps all of them -- to get lucrative seats on the combined company's board.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: In its offer, CVS has also agreed to cover any costs associated with stock option backdating at Caremark, practices that are under federal investigation and the subject of another civil suit filed against the company in Tennessee.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: That lawsuit has challenged 4.6 million options granted to Mr. Crawford as having been possibly backdated.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Stock sales covered by those options generated $262 million for Mr. Crawford, the Tennessee lawsuit contends.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: ''The inequities could not be more apparent,'' said Gerald H. Silk, a lawyer at Bernstein, Litowitz, Berger & Grossmann, one of the firms representing the Louisiana fund.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: ''Shareholders get a coercive, zero-premium deal while Crawford gets a $48 million payout, jobs for himself and his son and complete indemnification for his alleged option backdating transgressions.''

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: A Caremark spokesman called the pension fund's lawsuit meritless and said the company would defend against it vigorously.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: As for the Express Scripts suit, he said it was a ''frivolous'' attempt to interfere with the CVS merger.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: ''Contrary to allegations made by Express Scripts, the provisions of the CVS merger agreement are lawful and appropriate,'' the spokesman said.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: To be sure, many of the terms in the CVS bid for Caremark -- the no-shop provisions and last-look opportunity -- are common in the merger world.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: But the suit filed in Delaware, comes at a time when directors' actions as fiduciaries for their shareholders are under increased scrutiny.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: As a result, the case, which is being heard by Chancellor William B. Chandler III, provides an opportunity for him to opine on the matter of directors' duties broadly and whether the Caremark directors exercised those obligations in particular.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: This is familiar territory for Chancellor Chandler, who oversaw the Disney case of 2005.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: In that case he chastised the company's directors for essentially rubberstamping a contract struck by Michael D. Eisner with Michael S. Ovitz that resulted in a $140 million severance payout after Mr. Ovitz was terminated a short time later.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Chancellor Chandler has asked for a hearing on the issues before Caremark's shareholders vote on the CVS bid, now scheduled to take place in mid-March.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: In a Dec. 29 meeting with the parties in the case, Chancellor Chandler said that while he was certain Caremark would argue forcefully that its directors exercised their duties of care and loyalty to the company's owners, he also concluded that ''there is a tenable argument on the other side, and nonfrivolous claims here on the other side, that at least need to be tested against a fuller record.''

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: Correction: January 12, 2007, Friday An article in Business Day yesterday about a lawsuit filed by a pension fund over the proposed merger between Caremark RX and CVS misstated the amount of exit pay that Caremark's chief executive, Edwin M. Crawford, would receive if a rival bid was accepted.

column2: A Public Pension Fund Sues Directors of Caremark Rx
column3: If Express Scripts succeeds in its rival bid, Mr. Crawford would receive $57.6 million to $62.4 million, not an estimated $48 million.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: PARIS (Reuters) - French bank Natixis (CNAT.PA) said on Wednesday it planned to sell several specialized finance businesses to its parent, unlisted French cooperative lender BPCE, and use part of the 2.7 billion euros ($3.1 billion) in proceeds for acquisitions.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: FILE PHOTO: The logo of French bank Natixis is seen outside one of their offices in Paris February 18, 2013.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: REUTERS/Charles Platiau/File Photo

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: “This planned transaction would give Natixis further financial firepower to invest in its differentiating asset-light business lines – primarily asset management,” Chief Executive Francois Riahi said in a statement.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: Natixis said the deal would leave it with a war chest of 2.5 billion euros for acquisitions over the 2018-2020 period, up from 1 billion euros previously earmarked, although it currently has no specific new deals in the works.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: The bank has already spent 400 million euros of that amount on two acquisitions earlier this year, its CEO said.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: The French investment bank said it intends to pay shareholders a special dividend of 1.5 billion euros after the deal is closed during the first quarter next year if it doesn’t find acquisition opportunities.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: Natixis said the sale of assets will allow BPCE to widen the range of services it offers to its retail customers, while Natixis will beef up its profile as an investment bank.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: Natixis will narrow its focus to asset management, wealth management, investment banking, payment services and insurance.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: It intends to make acquisitions in all those businesses, except for insurance.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: If Natixis were to identify acquisition targets after the special dividend is paid to shareholders, BPCE would back it with capital if needed, BPCE’s Chief Executive Laurent Mignon said in a conference call with journalists.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: Mignon, Natixis’ CEO until June, is also chairman of the investment bank’s supervisory board.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: The assets to be sold to BPCE are consumer financing, factoring, leasing, sureties and guarantees, and securities services businesses.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: Following the transaction, Natixis expects to raise its target for return on tangible equity in 2020 to between 14 percent and 15.5 percent from a previous target of between 13 percent and 14.5 percent.

column2: Natixis to sell business lines to parent bank for $3.1 billion
column3: The bank will also lift its core equity tier one ratio to 11 percent from 10.5 percent at the end of the second quarter as it will keep 500 million euros in capital.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: MANILA, Nov. 20 (Xinhua) -- The Asian Development Bank (ADB) said on Tuesday that it has approved a 500-million-U.S. dollar emergency assistance loan to support Indonesia's recovery and rehabilitation of Lombok and Central Sulawesi after recent disasters.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: The Manila-based bank said the loan will provide immediate funding for the government's recovery and rehabilitation action plans, targeting urgent needs such as temporary shelters, social protection and services, as well as economic recovery through cash assistance, credit schemes and skills improvement programs.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: "ADB's emergency assistance loan provides timely and flexible financing to help mitigate the devastating impacts of the recent disasters," said Sona Shrestha, ADB's Director for Public Management, Financial Sector, and Trade Division for Southeast Asia.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: "The quick-disbursing loan modality will help ensure that post-disaster recovery and rehabilitation expenditures are met without compromising critical economic and social development expenditures in the national budget," she added.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: The Emergency Assistance for Recovery and Rehabilitation from Recent Disasters is part of ADB's response to two recent disasters that hit Indonesia including a magnitude-7.0 earthquake that struck Lombok, West Nusa Tenggara province, in August, and a magnitude-7.4 earthquake that struck Central Sulawesi province in September.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: These disasters claimed the lives of more than 2,600 people, injured some 18,000 people and displaced more than half a million, according to the ADB.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: The ADB said housing and public infrastructure have suffered extensive damage, adding that the impact of the Central Sulawesi disaster has been particularly severe as the earthquake caused landslides, tsunami, and liquefaction, a condition where the ground itself loses stability and takes on liquid properties.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: According to the ADB, the initial assessments suggest over 2.2 billion U.S. dollars in damage and losses in the affected provinces.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: In October, the bank approved an emergency grant of 3 million U.S. dollars from the Asia Pacific Disaster Respond Fund for immediate relief in Central Sulawesi.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: In addition, it is also supporting the Indonesian government with technical assistance in post-disaster needs assessments and reconstruction planning.

column2: ADB approves loan for disaster recovery in Indonesia - Xinhua
column3: The ADB said it is preparing new technical assistance to build capacity for robust monitoring, evaluation, and financial reporting of the rehabilitation and reconstruction plans.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Hedge funds have been very good to institutions like Yale.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: On its 2005 tax forms, the university reported annual income of $149 million from its hedge fund investments.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: And much of that income, which would have been taxable if derived from domestic hedge funds, was tax free because it was generated by offshore affiliates of such funds.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: That strategy of tax avoidance is one that many of the nation's wealthiest universities, as well as foundations and pension funds, have been using with great success.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Now Congress is considering closing the loophole that allows it.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: The goal is to raise money for the Treasury.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: The Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations, which has been looking into hedge fund practices, estimates that more than $100 billion in tax revenue a year is lost through the use of offshore tax havens and questionable tax shelters by investors of all types.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''A key concern is whether tax-exempt use of offshore corporations to invest in hedge funds is accelerating the shifting of U.S. assets offshore to avoid U.S. taxes,'' said Senator Carl Levin, the Michigan Democrat who heads the subcommittee and who is among the sponsors of legislation that would close a number of such loopholes.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: While nonprofit institutions are generally exempt from taxation, income produced by business activity that is deemed outside the scope of their mission may be subject to tax.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Under the tax code, profits from any activities financed with borrowed money, like much of the income from hedge fund and private equity investments, are taxable.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: But if the nonprofit invests in an offshore company, there is no tax.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: So hedge funds and private equity funds have set up offshore subsidiaries for nonprofits and other tax-exempt groups like pension funds to invest in.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: For instance, Farallon Capital Institutional Partners L.P. of San Francisco, a hedge fund in which Yale, the University of Michigan and other universities have invested, has a management company in the British Virgin Islands.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: The offshore company was created in large part to help nonprofits avoid taxes, Thomas F. Steyer, Farallon's senior managing partner, wrote investors in a letter in 2000.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: A 2005 article in the newsletter Tax Notes said Duke University sought to keep 25 percent of its endowment, which now stands at $7.4 billion, invested in hedge funds.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: At the time, about 75 percent of Duke's hedge fund investments were in offshore funds, according to the article, written by Maximilian H. Haag, a Duke law student who had interviewed the university's investment managers.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: But universities do not generally disclose what portion of their endowment is invested in offshore hedge funds, and so it is impossible to estimate how much tax they are avoiding.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: And their officials are wary of discussing the issue.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Spokesmen for 10 of the nation's wealthiest universities either did not respond to a reporter's messages or declined to make anyone from their investment management teams available.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''As a matter of policy, we do not comment on our portfolio,'' Cass Ciatt, a spokeswoman for Princeton, wrote in an e-mail message.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: David Jarmul, a spokesman for Duke, emphasized the university's support for research, its financial aid programs and the other benefits its endowment provides.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: The university invests ''in various ways to maximize returns,'' Mr. Jarmul said by e-mail.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''Like other universities, Duke uses legitimate tax-advantaged structures, always in accordance with applicable law.''

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: With growing signs of displeasure from Congress, however, there are indications that some universities are reconsidering the use of offshore entities as a tax-avoidance method.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''This practice is legal and has been approved by the Internal Revenue Service in a number of rulings,'' said Patrick Dunkley, senior counsel at Stanford University, whose endowment stood at $14.1 billion in 2006.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''We are nonetheless currently reviewing the investment strategy.''

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Congress made a pass at closing the loophole in 1993.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''I can tell you why I proposed it in one word: revenue,'' said former Representative Dan Rostenkowski, Democrat of Illinois, who was chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee from 1981 to 1994.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''That's the same thing driving them now.''

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Mr. Rostenkowski said that under ''pay as you go'' budget rules, which Congress adopted anew in January, ''you have to raise the revenue to feed this appetite we have for spending money.''

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: In some cases, hedge fund investors can realize returns as high as 40 percent or more.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: So while closing the loophole could mean additional taxes for nonprofits, it would be unlikely to reduce their investments in hedge funds and private equity funds significantly, said Leon M. Metzger, a former hedge fund executive who teaches hedge fund management at New York University.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''Because returns are so very attractive, unless Congress takes an extreme approach, I don't think this will have a major impact,'' Mr. Metzger said.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: In addition, two hedge fund partners who spoke only on condition of anonymity, for fear of alienating clients, said nonprofits could probably use other investment strategies to avoid taxes.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Foundations also use the loophole, although the nation's largest, the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, had no hedge fund investments at the end of last year.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Richard Tofel, the Rockefeller Foundation's general counsel, said 21 percent of its $3.7 billion endowment was invested in hedge funds and 12 percent in private equity funds.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: Mr. Tofel said he did not know what portion of those investments were offshore, but Rockefeller expects to pay $7 million in income taxes for 2006.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: He also said Rockefeller would be unlikely to end all its offshore investments if the law changed.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: ''Tax is part of what goes into the mix in making investment decisions,'' Mr. Tofel said, ''but on the other hand it's not the principal thing that drives investment decisions.

column2: Nonprofits Face Threat to a Tax Loophole
column3: You make judgments about underlying asset values, risk and reward, and taxes come in somewhere after that.''

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: BEIJING, Sept. 24 (Xinhua) -- China published a white paper on Monday to clarify the facts about China-U.S. economic and trade relations, demonstrate its stance on trade friction with the United States, and pursue reasonable solutions.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: Excluding the foreword, the 36,000-Chinese-character white paper is comprised of six parts, which are mutually-beneficial and win-win China-U.S. cooperation in the trade and economic field, clarification of the facts about China-U.S. trade and economic relations, the trade protectionist practices of the U.S. administration, the trade bullyism practices of the U.S. administration, damage of the improper practices of the U.S. administration to global economy, and China's position.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: China is the world's biggest developing country and the United States is the biggest developed country, said the white paper.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: "Trade and economic relations between China and the United States are of great significance for the two countries as well as for the stability and development of the world economy."

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: The white paper said the two countries are at different stages of development and have different economic systems, and therefore some level of trade friction is only natural.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: "The key, however, lies in how to enhance mutual trust, promote cooperation, and manage differences."

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: In the spirit of equality, rationality, and moving to meet each other halfway, the two countries have set up a number of communication and coordination mechanisms such as the Joint Commission on Commerce and Trade, the Strategic and Economic Dialogue, and the Comprehensive Economic Dialogue, the white paper said.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: Each has made tremendous efforts over the past 40 years to overcome all kinds of obstacles and move economic and trade relations forward, which has served as the ballast and propeller of the overall bilateral relationship, according to the white paper.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: However, the new administration of the U.S. government has trumpeted "America First" since taking office in 2017, and has abandoned the fundamental norms of mutual respect and equal consultation that guide international relations, said the white paper.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: "Rather, it has brazenly preached unilateralism, protectionism and economic hegemony, making false accusations against many countries and regions, particularly China, intimidating other countries through economic measures such as imposing tariffs, and attempting to impose its own interests on China through extreme pressure," according to the white paper.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: The white paper stressed China has responded from the perspective of the common interests of both parties as well as the world trade order, observing the principle of resolving disputes through dialogue and consultation, and answering the U.S. concerns with the greatest level of patience and good faith.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: The Chinese side has been dealing with these differences with an attitude of seeking common ground while shelving divergence, the white paper said.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: "It has overcome many difficulties and made enormous efforts to stabilize China-U.S. economic and trade relations by holding rounds of discussions with the U.S. side and proposing practical solutions."

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: However, the U.S. side has been contradicting itself and constantly challenging China, the white paper said.

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: "As a result, trade and economic friction between the two sides has escalated quickly over a short period of time, causing serious damage to the economic and trade relations which have developed over the years through the collective work of the two governments and the two peoples, and posing a grave threat to the multilateral trading system and the principle of free trade."

column2: China releases white paper on facts and its position on trade friction with U.S. - Xinhua
column3: The Chinese government published the white paper to clarify the facts about China-U.S. economic and trade relations, demonstrate China's stance on trade friction with the United States, and pursue reasonable solutions.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: PARIS (Reuters) - France has no plans for now to sell its 14 percent stake in Air France-KLM (AIRF.PA), Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire said on Thursday, pressing the group’s new chief executive to focus on increasing competitiveness.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: FILE PHOTO: French Finance Minister Bruno Le Maire attends a news conference at the Bercy Finance Ministry in Paris, France, August 30, 2018.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: REUTERS/Christian Hartmann/File Photo

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Le Maire was reacting to a warning from the group’s new Canadian boss, Benjamin Smith, to Air France’s labour unions that the government was prepared to offload its shares and they should not rely on the state to bail them out.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Smith, who took over the group last week, faces the unenviable task of having to overcome union resistance to reduce the French unit’s swollen cost base while keeping increasingly frustrated Dutch staff on side.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: A wave of strikes at Air France this spring cost the group some 350 million euros ($410 million) and led to the ouster of Smith’s predecessor.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: “Today the priority is to turn around Air France,” Le Maire told franceinfo.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: “Selling off the state’s stake in Air France is not part of Benjamin Smith’s action plan.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: It is not an option on the table today.”

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Shares in Air France KLM rose 1.6 percent, although the stock remains down by nearly 40 percent so far in 2018.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: In an interview published on Thursday, Smith told the Financial Times that the French government should not and would not bail out Air France to shield it from competition, even if there were some in the company that believed the state’s holding offered them protection.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Le Maire himself warned Air France staff in May that the government would not come to the airline’s rescue.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: The French state is the largest shareholder in Air France-KLM.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: What President Emmanuel Macron does with the stake will be a test of the former investment banker’s resolve to lighten the state’s touch on the economy.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Le Maire said it made no sense for the state to sell down its stake in Air France while the airline is attempting to make tough reforms and at a time its share price is suffering.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: “The state would be a poor manager (of its holdings) if it started selling its shares in a company that is not in good shape,” he said.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Air France-KLM’s shares have been hit this year, mainly due to the strikes waged by French unions seeking improved pay and working conditions.

column2: Minister to Air France-KLM boss: Fix airline before talk of stake sale
column3: Delta Airlines (DAL.N) and China Eastern Airlines (600115.SS) each hold an 8.8 percent stake in the group.

column3: "The Belt and Road is a great cause.

column3: As a witness and participant, I will be devoted to it with my Chinese colleagues," said the Lao manager.

column3: Bounthong Chitmany, deputy prime minister of the Lao government, spoke highly of the construction and operation of the Nam Ou cascade hydropower project and its contribution to local economic and social development.

column3: Back in the 1990s, Sinohydro Bureau 10 Co., LTD undertook the construction of Nam Leuk Hydropower Plant, which was widely praised by the local government and society.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Stocks have been a great investment in the last 80 years, with an average return of about 10 percent a year.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: But have investors in the stock market done as well as stocks?

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Surprisingly, the answer is no.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: The average dollar invested in the stock market in those years has earned only about 8.6 percent a year.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: The discrepancy between stock market return and investor return is examined by Ilia D. Dichev, a University of Michigan accounting professor, in a paper published in the March 2007 edition of The American Economic Review, ''What Are Stock Investors' Actual Historical Returns?

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Evidence From Dollar-Weighted Returns.''

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: To understand the difference between a stock's return and an investor's return, consider someone who buys 100 shares of a company at a price of $10 a share.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: A year later, the share price is up to $20, and the investor buys 100 more shares.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Alas, the investor's luck has run out.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: By the end of the next year, the price has fallen back to $10 and the investor sells his 200 shares.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: A buy-and-hold investor who bought at $10, held the stock for two years, and then sold at $10 would have had a zero return.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: But our friend who tried to time the market did much worse: over the two years, he invested $3,000 in the stock and ended up with only $2,000.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: E

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: ven though the stock broke even, the investor lost money because of bad timing: most of his money was invested right before the market fell.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: To calculate a meaningful measure of the investor's return, it is necessary to weight the yearly returns by the dollars invested during that year.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: When Mr. Dichev calculates the dollar-weighted returns on this stock according to his preferred method, our hypothetical investor's average yearly return ends up being negative 16.8 percent, far below the zero return that the buy-and-hold investor would have received.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Some mutual fund families and reporting services currently report dollar-weighted returns for individual investors and funds.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Mr. Dichev's contribution is to apply this methodology to the stock market as a whole, weighting each month's return by the amount of money invested in the market during that period.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: An investor who bought a value-weighted portfolio of stocks in the New York Stock Exchange and American Stock Exchange in 1926 and held them until 2002 would have earned an average annual return of about 10 percent.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: By contrast, an individual who bought in 1926 but moved his dollars in and out of the market in the same pattern as the average dollar invested in the market would have earned a return of only 8.6 percent a year.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: For Nasdaq, the difference between buy-and-hold and dollar-weighted returns is even larger.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: An investor who bought the Nasdaq index in 1973 and sold in 2002 would have earned an average yearly return of 9.6 percent.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: But the typical investor in Nasdaq earned only 4.3 percent over this period.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: This is true not just in the United States -- the same thing occurred in 18 of 19 international markets that Mr. Dichev examined.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: It appears that taken as a whole, investors just aren't very good at market timing.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: But why?

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: There's an old adage on Wall Street: ''Buy on the rumor, sell on the news.''

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Unfortunately, small investors do not seem to follow this rule.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: Terrance Odean, a finance professor at the University of California, Berkeley, has found that small individual investors tend to buy stocks when they are mentioned in the media: they buy on the news.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock
column3: The professional and institutional investors are happy to sell to retail investors in such periods.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column3: They often provide insightful reporting and in-depth analysis.

column2: Sometimes the Stock Does Better Than the Investor That Buys the Stock

column2: For Shareholders, a Ticket Into an $8 Billion Deal

column2: For Shareholders, a Ticket Into an $8 Billion Deal

column2: For Shareholders, a Ticket Into an $8 Billion Deal

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: BEIJING, Jan. 27 (Xinhua) -- China's latest campaign against organized crime and officials who hide criminal organizations reflects President Xi Jinping's outlook on security and his people-centered governance thought, according to academics.

column3: According to a document released by the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee and the State Council Wednesday, the fight will focus on industries and areas prone to organized crimes that prompt the "strongest public reaction" and that which is "detested" by the people.

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: The document said China would maintain a tough stance against "all types of organized crime."

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: The CPC Central Committee with Xi Jinping at its core has attached great importance to national security and people's security since the 18th CPC National Congress in 2012.

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: In the report delivered to the 19th CPC National Congress in 2017, Xi, also general secretary of the CPC Central Committee and chairman of the Central Military Commission, listed "pursuing a holistic approach to national security" as one of the 14 points underpinning China's endeavor to uphold and develop socialism with Chinese characteristics in the new era.

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: "We must put national interests first, take protecting our people's security as our mission and safeguarding political security as a fundamental task," Xi said.

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
column3: While addressing a seminar on national security in February last year, Xi said national security work was essential to protecting people's interests.

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua

column2: China Focus: Fight against organized crime reflects Xi's governance thought - Xinhua
