column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: STOCKHOLM, Sept. 9 (Xinhua) --- Polling stations opened in Sweden on Sunday morning as the country headed for an election that looks set to turn the nationalist Sweden Democrat Party into political kingmakers.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The final opinion polls published before Election Day predicted a neck-to-neck race between the center-left and center-right blocs, with the current government coalition partners -- the Social Democrats and the Greens -- along with the Left Party polling at 39.9 percent in a survey conducted by Novus on behalf of Swedish Television.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The four-party center-right Alliance was just behind, at 38.5 percent.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: In the same Novus poll, the Sweden Democrats came out second in terms of single party's support, with 19.1 percent of respondents opting for the party, which is often labeled as populist and far right.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: They have vowed to be tougher on immigration than any other political party in Sweden and want the Scandinavian nation to leave the European Union.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: In other recent polls, the Sweden Democrats have scored between around 16 and 25 percent, which would signify a significant boost compared to their 2014 election result, when they gained nearly 13 percent of the vote.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Immigration and integration have been central themes in Sweden's shorter-than-usual election campaign, with Election Day now scheduled on the second rather than the third Sunday of September.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Another Novus poll, published on Sept. 6, showed that immigration/integration is the second most important issue for Swedish voters, behind healthcare and ahead of schools/education.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Issues like crime and law and order have also dominated debates, especially after a series of car arson attacks in western Sweden last month and with gun violence on the rise, particularly in so-called "vulnerable areas" that are marred by social exclusion and relatively high crime rates.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: However, climate change also shot to prominence following this summer's unusually high temperatures and dramatic wildfires.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The Sweden Democrats, who want Sweden, at least temporarily, to stop taking in quota refugees as well as asylum seekers from countries outside of the Nordic region, have dominated the national conversation as the other seven parliamentary parties have positioned themselves against them, vowing not to form a government, or negotiate, with the party that is led by Jimmie Akesson.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: With neither political bloc set to gain a majority of the vote and neither willing to secure a majority by collaborating with the Sweden Democrats, the government formation question is still up in the air, with widespread talk of tactical voting among Swedes.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Analysts and commentators speculate that there will be political bargaining across the left-right divide after the votes are counted.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Sweden faced a similar deadlock situation in 2014, when a snap election was avoided because the center-right Alliance (made up of the Moderates, the Center Party, the Liberals and the Christian Democrats) decided to abstain from blocking the Social Democrat-Green Party budget in a deal known as the December Agreement.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: This time around, neither bloc has said they are willing to repeat such a deal, which proved controversial among the electorate and, some analysts say, helped boost support for the Sweden Democrats, cementing their self-appointed status as Sweden's "only opposition party".

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The Sweden Democrats, on their part, could end up with a key role in shaping the next government, even if they are unlikely to be part of one, as they may have the power to bring down any minority government that they oppose.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Under Sweden's negative parliamentarian system, a government does not need to have a majority in favor of it, as long as there is no majority against it.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The Sweden Democrats could support Kristersson's government or simply abstain from voting, thereby offering it passive support.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: The potential post-election scenarios and what role the Sweden Democrats will play have also dominated debates and party-leader interviews during the campaign.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: That was after he sparred with other party leaders in a televised debate on Friday evening over unemployment rates among immigrants, suggesting it is hard for newcomers to get jobs because they "do not fit in" and "are not Swedish".

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Akesson added that immigrants must get opportunities to become Swedish and to integrate into the labor market and wider society.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: While the Social Democrats on Sunday may get the lowest share of the vote in more than a century and the main opposition, the conservative Moderates, look set to lose their position as Sweden's second biggest party, smaller parties are doing comparatively well.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua
column3: Polls suggest that support for the ex-Communist Left Party could double compared to the 2014 election, and the Center Party -- an agrarian party that has shifted its focus towards free-market economics and in this election has staked its claims as the most liberal on immigration out of all the four opposition Alliance parties -- is now the fifth most popular party.

column3: That is according to the Sept. 6 Novus poll.

column2: Swedes head to polls in 2018 general elections - Xinhua

column2: Egypt to Vote on Expanding Powers of the Presidency

column2: Egypt to Vote on Expanding Powers of the Presidency

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: PARIS (Reuters) - Emmanuel Macron ripped up the French political textbook with surprising ease last year, but repeating the feat in Europe next year is a tall order when there are decades of perceived French arrogance to overcome.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Pieyre-Alexandre Anglade speaks during an interview with Reuters at a cafe in Paris, France, September 25, 2018.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: REUTERS/Richard Lough

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Pieyre-Alexandre Anglade, Macron’s European election emissary, has a front-seat role in persuading parties from across the left-right divide to rally behind the president’s drive to redraw the landscape and make Europe relevant again.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “Creating trust in politics takes time, creating trust in European politics takes more time, but creating trust in European politics when you’re French takes even more time,” the 31-year old soft-spoken lawmaker told Reuters in an interview.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Macron, who paints next May’s European elections as a battle between progressive, pro-EU reformists and populist, far-right nationalists, is out to break the old left-right duopoly that has dominated European politics in recent decades.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: He has tasked Anglade with seeking out future alliance partners from the existing conservative European People’s Party (EPP) and center-left Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D), as well as the smaller centrist ALDE group, to form a new movement inside the European Parliament.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “We see the system as dysfunctional and it needs rebuilding, but there’s no arrogance in our approach, we’re not here to say we’ll destroy everything because we’re the best.”

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: For all the professed humility, Macron is attempting nothing less than a brutal reshaping of the current political order in Brussels, just as he achieved in France, and a direct challenge to Europe’s most powerful leader, Germany’s Angela Merkel.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Merkel and Macron have forged a strong relationship, Anglade said, dismissing the suggestion Macron’s election strategy may put him on a collision course with the German chancellor, who is keeping faith with the EPP.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: But he acknowledged Germany was “the most complicated issue” for the coming elections.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “Obviously, from this point of view, our interests are not necessarily aligned,” Anglade said.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: If Macron’s future alliance is able to edge out the EPP to become the biggest grouping, it would hand him more influence over the pick of top EU jobs and more influence on EU legislation.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: No small feat for someone who only two years ago set up his own movement and blew apart France’s two-party system.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: ‘NUMBER ONE FORCE’

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Macron’s lieutenants have held talks with Italy’s center-left Democratic Party, which currently sits in the S&D group, and European Council leader Donald Tusk’s Civic Platform in Poland, which is aligned with the EPP.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: They have also met the leaders of Spain’s centrist Ciudadanos and Guy Verhofstadt, the leader of ALDE.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: On Thursday, his party chief Christophe Castaner penned an opinion column in European newspapers with Italy’s former prime minister Matteo Renzi, Verhofstadt and others.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “We must act now, or the European project will stall.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “But if we want to become the number one force, or a major force in the European parliament, we need to go beyond the ALDE base and be able to rally political parties which were once in the EPP, the Socialists or the Greens, in a new structure.”

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “There are a certain number of parties which went to the EPP or the Socialists at one point, not because they were conservatives or Socialists, but because that’s where power was and how you got posts,” Anglade said.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Macron has not designated a leader for his European ambitions and in another challenge to Brussels has said he will not present a “spitzenkandidat” - a group’s candidate to become the head of the European Commission.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: “The spitzenkandidat today is a man or a woman named by a political party in a dark room in Helsinki, Riga or wherever, who has no strong legitimacy,” Anglade said.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order
column3: Macron will seek businessmen, professionals and political novices to run for parliament on his party’s national ticket, just as he did in France last year, Anglade said.

column2: Killing them softly: Macron's EU election man challenges Brussels political order

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: BERLIN, Oct. 5 (Xinhua) -- Markus Soeder (CSU), the governor of Bavaria, has blamed infighting in the ruling "grand coalition" for the current weakness of his Christian Social Union (CSU) party in opinion polls during a televised appearance on Friday.

column3: "These are all numbers which are incredibly influenced by politics in Berlin," Soeder said with view to the latest Infratest dimap survey in which the CSU's voter support has slumped to 33 percent in its Bavarian homestead.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: He warned voters not to treat regional elections in his state as an opportunity to punish the federal government.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: The CSU, the conservative sister party of chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democratic Union (CDU), has traditionally dominated politics in Bavaria by defending an absolute legislative majority there throughout most of the post-war period.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: When polled in an Infratest dimap survey published on Thursday night, however, only 23 percent of voters said they wanted the CSU to continue ruling alone following an upcoming vote on Oct. 14.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: According to the survey, it would theoretically even be possible for the Free Democratic Party (FDP), Greens (Gruene), German Social Democrats (SPD) and Left Party (Linke) to form a government together without any participation of the incumbent.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: Responding to the poll, Soeder urged Bavarian voters to "reconsider for two seconds" before casting their ballot in less than two weeks.

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: "A game of a few seconds can become a five-year result."

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua

column2: Bavarian governor blames "grand coalition" for CSU slump in polls - Xinhua
column3: Commenting on the latest confrontation between Seehofer, Merkel and the SPD over his defense of the controversial ex-intelligence chief Hans-Georg Maassen, Soeder said that there was still room for improvement in the work of the "grand coalition".

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: People mourn the victim of the Aug. 25 attack in Chemnitz, eastern Germany, on Sept. 1, 2018.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: (Xinhua/Kevin Voigt)

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: by Maria Vasileiou

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: THE HAGUE, Sept. 16 (Xinhua) -- A fierce political row over migration policy triggered in Germany following violent anti-immigrant clashes in the city of Chemnitz, underlines a new line of conflict emerging within the European Union (EU) between nationalists and cosmopolitans, experts say.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "We have always defined much of European politics along the differences between Left and Right, but there is now a new line of conflict coming to the forefront, between nationalists and cosmopolitans, between those who are against migration and prefer closed borders and those, who are in favor of internationalism and openness," said Ben Crum, professor in political science at the Vrije University (VU) in Amsterdam.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: MIGRATION POLICY ROW REIGNITED

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: According to Crum, the political debate currently evolving in Germany, where the violent clashes in the city of Chemnitz reignited a row over migration policy, could be seen along this new line of conflict.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "The political debate in Germany is actually a fight over Angela Merkel's legacy, and it remains to be seen how German politics will evolve after the Chancellor concludes her term in office in some four years," the political expert told Xinhua, noting that "what happens in Germany is essential to the EU."

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Violent right-wing protests broke out in Chemnitz late in August, in the eastern German state of Saxony, following the killing of a German man for which two immigrants from Syria and Iraq were arrested.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: The clashes have deeply shaken German politics, reviving strains in German Chancellor's Angela Merkel's government and sparking an intense debate about Merkel's open border 2015 policy to let in more than a million refugees.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "In German politics a lot depends on how Merkel's Christian Democrats and their allies, the Christian Social Union (CSU), succeed in becoming a stable alliance again, managing to win back voters they lost in last September's elections to far-right Alternative for Germany (AfD)," said Mark Elchardus, Emeritus professor of sociology at the Vrij University of Brussels (VUB).

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Angela Merkel's government faced its deepest crisis since she became chancellor, when a dispute on migration policy between her party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and its ally, the Christian Social Union (CSU) broke out in June.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Anti-immigration sentiment, which according to Elchardus is on the rise across the EU despite a sharp drop in the actual number of migrants arriving to the European Union to pre-2015 level, holds a key role in the emerging line of conflict between nationalists and cosmopolitans in Europe.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "Today the migration crisis is more about how people react to new arrivals and not about how to actually manage the number of those reaching the EU," said Elchardus.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: The rate at which migrants are arriving has dropped sharply in Europe since the huge inflows in 2015.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: According to latest data available by Frontex, the EU's border and coast guard agency, in the first eight months of 2018 the number of irregular border crossings into the EU fell 40 per cent from a year ago to about 86 500.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: In 2015 more than one million refugees and migrants crossed into Europe.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: ORBAN VS MACRON

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "On the European scene the emerging extremes of the nationalist position versus the cosmopolitan one are best embodied by Hungary's prime minister Viktor Orban on one side and by French president Emmanuel Macron on the other," said Crum.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "Europe looks very much a struggle between what Macron stands for and what Orban stands for," agreed Elchardus, noting that it is unclear how this battle for influence will evolve, especially in regards to party alliance making in the run-up to European Parliament (EP) elections in May 2019.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "The opposition between them is very clear, Macron stands for liberal democracy, he is pro-European, whereas Orban advocates illiberal democracy, he is Eurosceptic and against immigration, but it is completely unclear how this is going to translate in alliances within the European parliament," the sociologist said.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Macron framed next year's European elections as a strong opposition "between nationalists and progressives" late in August, following statements by Italy's far-right Deputy Prime Minister Matteo Salvini and Orban, who labelled the French president their number one enemy.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Critical to further developments is whether Orban's Fidesz party remains within the conservative European People's Party (EPP), currently the largest grouping in the European Parliament.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "It is doubtful whether Orban's party will remain in the EPP," said Crum, noting that "it will be more natural to either be boosted out or to be moved to a more right-wing nationalist group within the EP."

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Orban said in June he would prefer Fidesz to stay within the EPP and try to reform the group from the inside, but EPP members, including Merkel's Christian Democrats, have criticized some of Orban's policies.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Macron's strategy for the European elections is decisive on how the balance of political powers along the conflict of nationalists versus cosmopolitans will evolve within the EU.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "Macron has not affiliated himself to any of the European political families and hasn't attempted to create his own group either," said Crum.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Moreover, big questions loom over Europe's Social Democrats.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: "The decline of social democracy and the inability of those parties to regain their initiative, is an important factor because they have the potential of stopping the rise of far-right, anti-immigration forces," said Elchardus.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: While Europe has seen a rise in support for far-right, anti-immigrant parties in recent national and regional elections, social democrats have experienced a sharp drop in popularity in several countries across the Continent, underlined by recent developments in Sweden.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: In last week's national elections in the Nordic country the Social Democrats' vote share fell to its lowest level since 1911, while the anti-immigration nationalists Sweden Democrats made gains.

column2: Analysis: Europe split between nationalists, cosmopolitans - Xinhua
column3: Elchardus anticipated further rise in support for anti-immigration, nationalist forces but he saw no majorities in Western European countries, where mainstream democratic parties "manage to contain the rise of far-right by getting tougher on migration and European integration positions".

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: BANDAR SERI BEGAWAN, Nov. 19 (Xinhua) -- China and Brunei on Monday agreed to upgrade their relations to a strategic cooperative partnership.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: The two countries also pledged to be good partners featuring mutual trust in politics, mutual benefit in economy, mutual understanding in people-to-people and cultural exchanges, and mutual assistance in multilateral affairs.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: The consensus was reached during talks between visiting Chinese President Xi Jinping and Brunei's Sultan Haji Hassanal Bolkiah.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: "The decision made by our two sides to establish a strategic cooperative partnership is to ... deliver greater benefits to our two peoples through our cooperation," Xi said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Xi arrived here on Sunday for a state visit to Brunei, the first by a Chinese head of state in 13 years to the Southeast Asian nation.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: During the talks, Xi expressed high appreciation to the Sultan for the great importance he has long attached to developing the China-Brunei relations.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: The Chinese president said he was deeply impressed by the warmth and hospitality of the Bruneian people on his first visit to the country, which Xi said vividly testifies to the profound friendship between the two peoples.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Xi praised the bilateral ties, saying that China and Brunei enjoy a long and deep historical and cultural link, and are close neighbors across the sea as well as friends and partners who trust each other.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: PLANNING FOR FUTURE

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: During the talks, Xi called on the two sides to increase high-level exchanges to well steer the vessel of bilateral relations.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: China appreciates Brunei's firm adherence to the one-China policy and will continue to support Brunei in pursuing a development path that suits its own national conditions, Xi said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: China sees Brunei as an important partner for cooperation in building the 21st Century Maritime Silk Road and is willing to align the Belt and Road Initiative with Brunei's Wawasan 2035, a strategy for economic diversification, in a bid to boost the mutually beneficial cooperation between the two countries, he said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei's businesses are welcome to expand exports to China, Xi said, adding that China stands ready to strengthen cooperation with Brunei in infrastructure construction, agriculture, fishery, energy and other areas, and share the experience in developing digital economy, e-commerce and other emerging sectors.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: The Chinese president urged the two sides to enhance cooperation in education, culture, sports, health and tourism, promote understanding and friendship between the youths, expand exchanges at sub-national level, and boost cooperation in judiciary, counter-terrorism and crackdown on cross-border crime.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Xi also proposed that the two countries deepen communication, coordination and collaboration within the frameworks such as the United Nations and the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC), and jointly promote greater development in China-ASEAN relations and East Asia cooperation.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: China supports the Brunei Darussalam-Indonesia-Malaysia-Philippines East ASEAN Growth Area (BIMP-EAGA) cooperation and ASEAN in achieving a comprehensive, balanced development, he said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: On the South China Sea, Xi pointed out that it is in the vital interests of both China and Brunei to safeguard peace and stability in the South China Sea and also the shared aspiration of both peoples.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Xi said that China appreciates the dual-track approach proposed by Brunei: disputes should be handled through friendly consultation by parties concerned and countries in the region should jointly safeguard stability in the South China Sea.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Both sides should continue to advance maritime cooperation and the negotiations on the Code of Conduct (COC) in the South China Sea, thus building the sea into a sea of peace, friendship and cooperation, he added.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: For his part, Hassanal extended warm welcome to Xi for his first state visit to Brunei, saying that the visit will deepen the traditional friendly relations between the two countries and strengthen mutually beneficial cooperation in all areas.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: He said that Brunei and China enjoy a long history of friendship and the bilateral relations have continuously developed on the basis of mutual respect and mutual benefit.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: The Sultan said he is delighted that the bilateral ties were upgraded to a strategic cooperative partnership during Xi's visit.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei firmly adheres to the one-China policy and will take this visit as an opportunity to promote bilateral cooperation in trade, investment, agriculture, tourism, education, people-to-people and cultural exchanges, and judicial assistance, thus benefiting the two peoples, he said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei admires China for its remarkable achievements in poverty reduction and sustainable development, and is willing to promote synergy and cooperation between the Wawasan 2035 and the Belt and Road Initiative, Hassanal said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: He said that Brunei highly appreciates the important role of China in fostering global stability and prosperity, tackling climate change, safeguarding multilateral trading system, and promoting regional economic integration, and is grateful to China for supporting BIMP-EAGA cooperation.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei stands ready to increase communication and coordination with China in international and regional affairs, and push forward ASEAN-China cooperation to a deeper level, he said.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei is delighted that countries in the region jointly safeguard peace and stability in the South China Sea and advance maritime cooperation through dialogue and consultation, he added.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: After the talks, the two heads of state witnessed the signing of a cooperation plan on jointly promoting the Belt and Road Initiative and other bilateral cooperation documents.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: A joint statement was also issued.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: A grand welcome ceremony was held at Istana Nurul Iman, Brunei's royal palace, where Xi talked to members of Brunei's royal family.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: He told them that the Chinese side appreciates the long-term friendly policy upheld by the royal family toward China and the traditional friendship will be carried forward.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Xi also welcomed them to visit China more often.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: Brunei is the second stop of Xi's ongoing Asia-Pacific tour, which has already taken him to Papua New Guinea.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: He will also visit the Philippines.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: In Papua New Guinea, Xi paid a state visit and attended the 26th APEC Economic Leaders' Meeting.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua
column3: He also met with leaders of eight Pacific island countries that have diplomatic ties with China.

column2: China, Brunei lift ties to strategic cooperative partnership - Xinhua

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Three Republican senators voiced fresh concerns on Sunday about Attorney General Alberto R. Gonzales's handling of the dismissals of eight United States attorneys amid questions about whether the firings were politically motivated.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: The comments, made in separate televised interviews by Republicans with histories of breaking with the White House, provided further indication of waning support for Mr. Gonzales where he needs it most, among fellow Republicans.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Questions over Mr. Gonzales's future intensified on both sides of the aisle this weekend, after the release of Justice Department documents late Friday that detailed plans for a meeting between Mr. Gonzales and his aides in which they discussed the dismissals last year, 10 days before most of them happened.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Gonzales had previously said that he was ''not involved in any discussions about what was going on'' and that he had mostly followed the process from a distance.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Speaking on ''Meet the Press'' on NBC, Senator Arlen Specter, Republican of Pennsylvania, said he spoke with Mr. Gonzales on Saturday and told him ''he was going to have to have an explanation as to why he said he wasn't involved in discussions -- that's the key word -- and now you have these e-mails which appear to contradict that.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: White House officials continued to defend Mr. Gonzales, saying the e-mail messages did not directly contradict anything he had said and noting that he had not disputed that at the end of the process he signed off on the final list of prosecutors to be dismissed.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: President Bush said in his Saturday radio address that he strongly supported Mr. Gonzales in the decision to oust the prosecutors, though he has said he believes that more explanation is necessary.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Specter said Sunday that he would withhold judgment until he could learn more about the dismissals in Congressional testimony from Mr. Gonzales and others.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: But he added: ''We have to have an attorney general who is candid, truthful.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: And if we find he has not been candid and truthful, that's a very compelling reason for him not to stay on.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Specter, who has split with the administration on issues including domestic spying and the legal rights of terror suspects, is the ranking member of the Senate Judiciary Committee.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Speaking on ''This Week'' on ABC, Senator Chuck Hagel, Republican of Nebraska, said of Mr. Gonzales, ''He does have a credibility problem,'' adding, ''I think he's going to have some difficulties.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Asked by the host, George Stephanopoulos, whether Mr. Gonzales could serve effectively given the questions about his credibility, Mr. Hagel responded, ''Well, I do not, and I think the president is going to have to make a tough choice here.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Hagel has been a major Republican critic of Mr. Bush's handling of the Iraq war and is a potential 2008 presidential candidate.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Senator Lindsay Graham, Republican of South Carolina and a member of the Judiciary Committee, said on ''Face the Nation'' on CBS, ''I really do like Attorney General Gonzales, but he has been wounded.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Graham added: ''He's going to have to come to the Senate and re-establish his credibility.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: He's going to have to prove to us that there was a legitimate reason this was poorly handled.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: All three senators broke with the White House over conditions for possible Congressional interviews in the matter with White House aides, including Karl Rove, the president's top political adviser, and Harriet E. Miers, the former White House counsel.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: The president has offered to allow the aides to sit for private interviews with Congress if the sessions are not transcribed or conducted under oath.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Graham, Mr. Hagel and Mr. Specter said the interviews should at least be transcribed for the sake of accuracy and transparency.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: On Sunday, the White House found its strongest Republican defender in a onetime adversary, Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the Republican whip.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: In an interview on ''Fox News Sunday,'' Mr. Lott mocked the Democrats for charging that politics were involved in decisions involving political appointees.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: ''The horrors of horrors -- my goodness,'' Mr. Lott said.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: ''How were they selected in the first place?''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Mr. Lott also defended Mr. Bush's decision to invoke executive privilege in refusing to provide his aides for sworn testimony before Congress, saying ''he'd be making a huge mistake'' if he decided otherwise.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Later Sunday, the Democratic National Committee provided a list of quotations from Mr. Lott criticizing former President Bill Clinton for invoking executive privilege during the investigation into his relationship with Monica Lewinsky, including one in 1998 in which Mr. Lott called it improper and said, ''It looks like they are hiding something.''

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: Also on Sunday, in an interview on ''Late Edition'' on CNN, Senator Orrin G. Hatch, Republican of Utah and a member of the Judiciary Committee, defended the terms under which Mr. Bush said his aides could be interviewed and said he still had full confidence in Mr. Gonzales.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: And on ''Fox News Sunday,'' Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, who initially held off from calling for Mr. Gonzales's resignation, said: ''I believe he should step down.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: And I don't like saying this.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: This is not my natural personality at all.

column2: Republican Senators Express Reservations Over Gonzales
column3: But I think the nation is not well-served by this.''

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The new Democratic majority in Congress is divided over how to assert its power in opposing President Bush's plan to send more troops to Baghdad, as leaders explore ways to block financing for a military expansion without being accused of abandoning American forces already in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: While Democrats find themselves unusually united in their resistance to a troop increase, party leaders are locked in an internal debate over how far to go in objecting to the administration's Iraq strategy.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The White House has invited some Democrats to meet with Mr. Bush before he gives his Iraq speech on Wednesday, even as others have scoured the history books to find cases when Congress has reined in the commander in chief.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: In the most aggressive of the new tactics, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, has said he will introduce legislation on Tuesday to require the president to gain new Congressional authority before sending more troops to Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The bill is the first proposal in the Senate that would prohibit paying for an increase in American troops over their level on Jan. 1.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''Is there any American in this country who thinks the United States Senate would vote to support sending American troops into a civil war in Iraq today?''

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Mr. Kennedy said Monday in an interview.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''Is there any American that believes this?

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: I don't think so, but that is what's happening, and we have to do everything we can to insist on accountability.''

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The Kennedy plan is intended to provide Democrats with a road map for how to proceed in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Mr. Kennedy, as he begins his 45th year in the Senate, recalled that Congress interceded during conflicts in Vietnam and Lebanon, and he said Democrats should not hesitate to do so in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The new House speaker, Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, has similarly suggested that Democrats consider blocking financing for a troop increase, and the Senate majority leader, Harry Reid of Nevada, vowed Monday ''to take a look at it.''

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: But the House majority leader, Representative Steny H. Hoyer of Maryland, has not endorsed the idea.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Other Democrats, either looking ahead to a possible presidential candidacy or their own re-elections, have also distanced themselves from such a proposal, fearful of being cast as opposing the troops.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''I don't think we should be pulling back any funds,'' said Senator Amy Klobuchar, a Minnesota Democrat who was elected in November.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: She said she would oppose a proposal to block money for a troop increase.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The Democratic Party sailed to victory in midterm elections in the fall on a promise to change course in Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Still, there is little consensus over how to proceed.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Some Democrats are urging an immediate withdrawal of troops and a drastic reduction in war spending.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Others are calling for a gradual re-deployment of troops to move them out of Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Still other Democrats are waiting for Mr. Bush to present his plan before criticizing it.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The expectations set by the elections, Democrats say, present a complicating challenge as they begin to govern.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Take, for example, Mr. Reid, who said on Dec. 17 that he would support a plan for a temporary increase in increase troops.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Two weeks later, he announced his opposition, saying his change had nothing to do with other Democratic senators having spoken out against it, but rather with military officials having disagreed with a call for more troops.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Senator Russell D. Feingold, Democrat of Wisconsin, said he believed that his party lost the White House in 2004 because of Iraq.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''My concern now is that too many Democrats are going to want to play it safe on this issue and not take the strong stand that American people demand,'' he said Monday.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: The pressure from war critics on the Democratic left has been particularly intense.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''The bottom line is that they were elected on a mandate to get the nation out of the mess in Iraq,'' said Eli Pariser, the executive director of MoveOn.org, a liberal political action committee.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: By law, Congress can limit the nature of troop deployments, cap the size of military deployments and cut financing for existing or prospective deployments.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Since 1970, there have been dozens of occasions in which Congress has tried to step into military action, from Haiti to Bosnia to Kosovo, according to a memorandum being sent Tuesday to lawmakers by the Center for American Progress, a liberal policy group.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Representative Adam Smith of Washington, vice chairman of the moderate New Democratic Coalition, said he feared that withholding financing -- even for new troops being sent to Iraq -- could have a detrimental effect on all forces.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''I don't want our troops to be caught between the president and Congress in a political fight,'' said Mr. Smith, who was to receive a briefing on Tuesday at the White House.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''If there are any risks that our efforts to slash the budget would place them at greater risk, that would be unacceptable to me.''

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: But Democrats who are trying to stop Mr. Bush's proposed troop increase, a group led by Mr. Kennedy, say their proposal to block financing will apply only to new troops.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: Mr. Kennedy said he hoped that his legislation would be urgently considered by the full Senate, but acknowledged that it remained an open question whether his Democratic leaders would schedule it for a quick vote.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''The importance of this legislation is that it will apply now before we could get the escalation,'' he said.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: ''If you wait, this thing is going to be past.

column2: Democrats Split Over Iraq Approach
column3: I'm not sure that all of our colleagues in the Senate understand that, quite frankly.''

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: by Mohamed al-Azaki

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: SANAA, Dec. 2 (Xinhua) -- The United States has been mounting pressure to bring an end to the war in Yemen that is pitting its close allies in the Saudi-led coalition against Iranian-allied Shiite Houthi rebels.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: After more than three years of devastating war that killed thousands and brought the whole Yemeni nation to the brink of starvation, why is the United States stepping up its pressures now?

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: The U.S. Secretary of Defense James Mattis has called for "immediate end" to the war in Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "It looks like very, very early in December up in Sweden we'll see both the Houthi rebel side and the Saudi-backed government of Yemeni President Abd-Rabbu Mansour Hadi will be up there," Mattis told reporters at the Pentagon last week.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Mattis' words were quickly backed by the U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: In the U.S. Congress, many senators have risen their voices to end the U.S. military support to Saudi Arabia, increasing pressure on Trump administration to end the war in Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: They are now preparing to pass a legislation to completely end the U.S. military assistance to Saudi Arabia.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Also, many European countries, including France, have backed the calls for ending the conflict in Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Some European governments announced a pause of their weapon sales to Saudi Arabia.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Britain sent its Foreign Secretary Jeremy Hunt to Riyadh to press for an end to the Yemen's war.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Now, after such unprecedented push, the United Nations is well confident that all rival parties to the conflict will engage in those upcoming peace process.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: These accelerating moves are raising a question, why now?

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "The U.S. diplomatic movements have begun in early October, after the Western media began to learn about details of the murder of Saudi journalist Jamal Khashoggi," said Abdelelah Haidar, a Yemeni political analyst and an expert on the U.S. political issues based in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Jamal Khashoggi, a Saudi dissident, who was a journalist for The Washington Post, was reportedly assassinated inside the Saudi consulate in Istanbul on Oct. 2.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: The Saudi government has since been facing increasing pressure to disclose the perpetrators behind the murder of Khashoggi, as well as to end its war in Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "It appeared to be a U.S. military decision by the Pentagon chief Mattis as he was the first U.S. official to demand an immediate end to the Saudi-led coalition war in Yemen," Haidar told Xinhua.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Before Mattis' move, many voices in the Congress, which are very critical to the administration of U.S. President Donald Trump, have increasingly demanded the punishment against the murders of Khashoggi and called for an end to the Yemen's war.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "The victory of democrats in the midterm elections in the Congress in late October has sped up the pressure on Trump's administration," Haidar said.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "The democratic's senators were backed by a large-scale support from the leading U.S. media outlets, which focused on the Saudi-led coalition war in Yemen and linked it with the murder of Khashoggi," he said.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "I think, the Congress' pressure is targeting Trump himself ... it targeted the personal business relationship between Trump, his son-in-law Jared Kushner and the Saudi royal family," Haidar said.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Analyst Adel al-Assar of Sanaa-based daily Althawra newspaper said that "all comes together, the Congress' actions and U.S. media reports on Yemen's war, to put Trump administration to do something."

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "The democrats in the Congress are preparing to move ahead toward a complete cut of the U.S. military assistance to Saudi Arabia," al-Assar said.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "So, Trump and Kushner have their own personal motive to save Saudi Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman, whom they have a very special friendship," he added.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: The Congress' movements and Trump's "personal motivation" are two important factors that could probably explain what was behind the U.S. quick action towards its close ally Saudi Arabia and the war of Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: The same movements could also be seen recently in the discussions inside the British House of Commons and the House of Lords, which focused on Khashoggi's murder and the war in Yemen.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: Professor Ali al-Ammary of the Faculty of Media in Sanaa University argued that the increasing pictures of Yemen's war, particularly the airstrikes, the Yemeni malnourished children and depressed Yemeni families on western media front pages, were the key factor behind the recent international pressure to end the war.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "The peoples in the U.S. and Europe have become aware that millions of Yemeni children are dying from malnutrition, starvation and epidemic diseases as a result from the Saudi-led coalition naval blockade for more than three years," said al-Ammary.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: It was an "ignored war" for many months because many western journalists had been denied access to Yemen, by now the international media organizations have become more active in reporting daily tragedies of millions of Yemenis.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "It has become facts that are shown by international media outlets, newspapers and televisions on a daily basis, and that put pressure on the U.S. and Britain to take an action now to stop this conflict," al-Ammary said.

column2: News Analysis: Why does U.S. push urgently for peace process in Yemen now? - Xinhua
column3: "I think it's the right moment to push for the Yemen peace, which represents all the best opportunity to date," he added.

column2: New East Timor PM pledges to bring unity after political deadlock

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: With both houses of Congress now firmly on record in favor of withdrawing from Iraq, President Bush vowed Wednesday not to negotiate a timetable with Democrats, and a confrontation appeared inevitable as each side prepared to blame the other for delays in providing money for the war.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: ''Now, some of them believe that by delaying funding for our troops, they can force me to accept restrictions on our commanders that I believe would make withdrawal and defeat more likely,'' Mr. Bush told an audience of cattlemen and ranchers.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: ''That's not going to happen.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: If Congress fails to pass a bill to fund our troops on the front lines, the American people will know who to hold responsible.''

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: Mr. Bush and Congressional Democrats are already deadlocked over the Democrats' demands for testimony from top White House officials in an inquiry into the firing of federal prosecutors.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: The president's remarks on Wednesday, a day after the Senate voted for the first time in favor of setting a withdrawal date, set the stage for a second clash.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: That puts Mr. Bush in the difficult position of fighting the new Democratic majority on two fronts, both the war spending and the prosecutors.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: On Wednesday, he seemed in no mood to back down from the war spending fight.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: As he quoted a newspaper editorial -- from The Los Angeles Times, though he did not mention it by name -- accusing Democrats of ''the worst kind of Congressional meddling in military strategy,'' Mr. Bush appeared almost eager for a battle.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: And Democrats seemed eager to give it to him.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House speaker, said Mr. Bush should ''calm down with the threats,'' and Senator Harry Reid of Nevada, the Democratic leader, said his impression was that Mr. Bush ''doesn't want anything other than a confrontation.''

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: The president has been saying for weeks that he will veto any war spending bill that contains a withdrawal date.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: He reiterated that threat on Wednesday, taking particular aim at Democrats for loading the military spending bills with unrelated special interest projects above the $100 billion he has asked for the war, including $3.5 million for visitors to ''tour the Capitol and see for themselves how Congress works,'' and $6.4 million for the House of Representatives' ''salaries and expense accounts.''

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: ''I don't know what that is,'' Mr. Bush said wryly, ''but it's not related to the war and protecting the United States of America.''

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: The House approved its version of the spending bill last week, and the Senate was expected to approve its version on Thursday.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: Democrats said they were ready to begin House-Senate negotiations quickly to produce a final version to send to the president.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: But with Congress scheduled to begin its Easter recess on Friday, it is nearly impossible for lawmakers to produce a final bill before the week of April 16.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: With Mr. Bush warning that funds will run out on April 15, forcing the Pentagon to draw from other accounts, the two sides seem certain to wind up in a blame game over who is responsible for holding up the money.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: The Democratic leaders, Ms. Pelosi and Mr. Reid, tried to strike a conciliatory tone, stressing that they would deliver all the money Mr. Bush requested.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: In a joint letter to the president, they said they stood ready to work with the White House.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout
column3: ''But your threats to veto a bill that has not even been presented to you indicate that you may not be ready to work with us,'' the letter said.

column2: Bush Rules Out Bid by Congress for Iraq Pullout

column2: Italy's Conte sworn in as PM of anti-establishment government

column2: Italy's Conte sworn in as PM of anti-establishment government

column3: MANILA, Dec. 12 (Xinhua) -- The Philippine Congress granted President Rodrigo Duterte's request to further extend martial law and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in Mindanao for a period of one year to Dec. 31, 2019, to quell a "continuing rebellion" in the southern Philippine region.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: After deliberating for almost four hours in a special joint session on Wednesday, lawmakers from both the Senate and the House of Representatives voted 235-28-1 in favor of another one-year extension of martial rule in Mindanao.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: This is the third extension granted to Duterte since he imposed martial law in May 2017 after rebellion militants laid siege to Marawi City.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: Under the martial law and the suspension of the privilege of the writ of habeas corpus in Mindanao, security forces are allowed to make arrests, detain or search without a warrant.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: This means that people who have committed the crime of rebellion or even suspected ones may be arrested without a warrant of arrest, and objects that are used in the commission of the crime of rebellion may be seized without a search warrant.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: With the extension of martial law, Philippine Presidential Spokesperson Salvador Panelo said the Duterte government "expects to achieve substantial progress in addressing the persisting rebellion in Mindanao, as well as promoting the overall security and peace and order situation in the island."

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: In a letter to Congress last week, Duterte asked lawmakers to allow the martial law to continue in Mindanao to quell terrorist groups that "continue to defy the government by perpetrating hostile activities."

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: In justifying his request for a third extension of martial law in Mindanao, Duterte added that despite the significant progress, "rebellion still persists in Mindanao and that the public safety requires the continuation of martial law in the whole of Mindanao."

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: Mindanao has been the hotbed of violent extremism and a brewing rebellion for decades.

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua

column3: The team called upon Congress to allow the further extension of martial law "to assist the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), the Philippine National Police (PNP) and all other enforcement agencies to put a decisive end to this ongoing rebellion and, thereby, remove a long-standing obstacle to the full rehabilitation and development of Mindanao."

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua

column2: Philippine Congress grants Duterte's request for extension of martial law in Mindanao - Xinhua
column3: Duterte initially imposed a 60-day martial law in Mindanao on May 23, 2017, after militants laid siege to Marawi, a predominantly Muslim city in Mindanao.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: KUALA LUMPUR (Reuters) - Malaysia’s general election this week will be an extraordinary contest, pitting a 92-year-old former authoritarian leader and a jailed reformist he fell out with 20 years ago against a prime minister who has been mired in a multi-billion-dollar scandal.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: FILE PHOTO - A combination photo of Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak and former Malaysian prime minister Mahathir Mohamad (R) in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, January 25, 2016 and March 30, 2017 (R).

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: REUTERS/Olivia Harris REUTERS/Lai Seng Sin(R)/File Photos

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: But a robust challenge from the opposition - spearheaded by nonagenarian Mahathir Mohamad, the country’s longest-serving prime minister, and his one-time protege Anwar Ibrahim - has produced the most hotly contested election yet.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: “Momentum is with the opposition, but we believe it is unlikely that they will pull off a surprise victory,” said the Eurasia Group consultancy, which put the odds of a win for Mahathir’s Pakatan Harapan (Alliance of Hope) at 15 percent.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: However, the political risk group’s Asia director, Peter Mumford, said there is a danger for the ruling coalition that it will fare worse than the 2013 election, when for the first time it lost the popular vote but still won with 133 of parliament’s 222 seats.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: Under Malaysia’s simple majority system, the party that gets the most seats in parliament wins even if it does not secure the popular vote.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: An unconvincing victory would leave Najib, 64, with reduced political clout and he could face pressure from within his party to stand aside ahead of the next election, Mumford said.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: That would be a blow for Najib, who has survived an uproar surrounding 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB), a state fund that racked up heavy debt after he took power in 2009.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: The prime minister has consistently denied any wrongdoing over the billions of dollars that were allegedly siphoned off from the state fund and he has been cleared of any offence by Malaysia’s attorney general.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia
column3: Mahathir sacked Anwar as his deputy prime minister in 1998.

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Clash of political titans brings a gripping election to Malaysia

column2: Thai junta chief eyes role in politics after election
