column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Miles and miles of bigger and stronger levees have been built along the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers since the deadly floods of 1993, and millions of dollars have been spent on drainage improvements.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Yet as the rush of water that caused the Missouri River to overflow its banks and submerge dozens of towns last week rolled toward St. Louis on Monday, attention was turned to a metropolitan region that since 1993 has seen runaway residential and commercial development in the rivers' flood paths.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: About 28,000 homes have been built and more than 6,000 acres of commercial and industrial space developed on land that was underwater in 1993, according to research by Nicholas Pinter, a geologist who studies the region at Southern Illinois University in Carbondale.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Building is happening on flood plains across Missouri, but most of the development is in the St. Louis area, and it is estimated to be worth more than $2.2 billion.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Though scientists warn about the danger of such building, the Missouri government has subsidized some of it through tax financing for builders.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''No one has really looked at the cumulative effect,'' said Timothy M. Kusky, a professor of natural sciences at St. Louis University, who calculates that there has been more development on the Missouri River flood plain in the years since 1993 than at any other time in the history of the region.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The good news for St. Louis right now is that forecasters say the two rivers will crest well below their 1993 levels by Tuesday, sparing the area significant flooding.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: But many scientists remain concerned that the effect of the new construction, should a levee break, could eventually be even more severe flooding.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Levees constrict a river's path and raise its water level, which causes higher, faster flow.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: A flood plain, conversely, exists in nature to absorb a river's overflow.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''The more levees we build, the higher we have to build them,'' Professor Kusky said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''It's a self-perpetuating problem.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Still, people have been drawn to the area, assured by the sense of security the levees provide.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Disincentives beyond the possibility of flooding seem to be few.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''This was absolutely a dodged bullet,'' Professor Pinter said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''This could have been a very bad situation for St. Louis, but luckily it was a near-miss.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: People living in the flood plains are eligible for the National Flood Insurance Program or for any private insurance they can secure, though the private alternatives are increasingly difficult to obtain.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: And they are entitled to whatever federal disaster relief is offered to the state after a flood, be it temporary housing or buyouts, said Butch Kinerney, a spokesman for the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: THF Realty Inc. used Missouri's tax program, known as tax increment financing, to build what is said to be the largest strip mall in the country on land in the Chesterfield Valley area of St. Louis County that was submerged in the floods of 1993.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The shopping center, which cost $275 million to build, opened in 1999 and now has more than two million square feet of retail space, mall officials said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The developers spent more than $35 million on levee and storm drainage improvements, replacing an old levee that had offered protection against a 100-year flood with a levee that met the standards for a 500-year flood.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: And, they said, they have brought jobs and revenue to a formerly sleepy part of the county.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''We built the shopping center and interchange that opened the entire valley,'' said Marian Nunn, the chief operating officer of THF Realty.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''The difference is that the levee is maintained now, on top of being bigger, stronger and better.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The risks are really substantially mitigated.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The company was able to use the special financing because Missouri allows it for projects in areas that are considered blighted, or where development is not likely to occur without help.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''We will continue to build even more,'' Ms. Nunn said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Faith in the levees seems to trump other concerns here.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''We're not even close to having any issues,'' said Brian McGownd, the deputy director of public works in Chesterfield.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Of the new levee, Mr. McGownd said, ''We have 100 percent confidence that it's done right, and the way it's supposed to be, and that it will be a good, strong levee for many years.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Fear of flooding did not appear to scare off prospective buyers at the New Town at St. Charles, a housing development whose sales office hummed with activity on Sunday, even as the Missouri River was rising.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Although the community is near the confluence of the Missouri and Mississippi Rivers, residents are not required to have flood insurance, because they are beyond the 100-year flood plain.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The location was a selling point for Ken Snider, a high school teacher from St. Louis.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''It's not going to flood here for another 100 years,'' Mr. Snider said, ''and I won't be around by then.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: But critics of the developments say someone else is likely to be around then, and taxpayers in general will carry the tab after the next disaster bailout.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''If history tells us anything, it's that levees once built eventually fail,'' Professor Pinter said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''But instead of being farmland there, now it's a strip mall or residential area, or a whole city.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: The floods of 1993 killed 38 people and caused $16 billion in damage across the Midwest.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: More than 500 counties were declared federal disaster areas.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Adolphus A. Busch IV, a member of the Anheuser-Busch brewing family who helped found the Great Rivers Habitat Alliance in St. Louis in 2000, is alarmed at the pace of development in the rivers' paths after the 1993 flood.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''That was the milestone for us,'' Mr. Busch said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Some people already living in the flood plain at the time of the last big flood now say that it just makes economic sense for them to stay close to the river, and that it is an issue of personal-risk calculation and property rights.

column3: ''They all took the buyout,'' Mrs. Hulst said of her neighbors who relocated after the flood.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''I took the buyout on a trailer I owned across the street, but you didn't make enough money to buy anything decent.''

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Today, Mrs. Hulst's trailer is elevated on three rows of cinder blocks.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''We'll be fine as long as the Mississippi doesn't back up,'' she said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: Alan Dooley, a spokesman for the Army Corps of Engineers, St. Louis District, said people, like water, had certain natural inclinations.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''People have a tendency to locate near water,'' Mr. Dooley said.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: ''These people vote; they pay taxes.

column2: Development Rises on St. Louis Area Flood Plains
column3: It's kind of difficult to go through with a broad brush and say, 'You all ought to get out of here.'

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: BADDAGANA, Sri Lanka (Thomson Reuters Foundation) - On the surface, Sri Lanka’s capital Colombo looks like any other fast-growing South Asian city, with buildings stretching as far as the eye can see and skyscrapers rearing up along its coast.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: But beneath the concrete, Colombo hides a wilder and wetter past.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Before it became the nerve center of Sri Lankan politics and business, the city was a region dotted with wetlands and about 30 km (19 miles) of canals that helped absorb and disperse the massive rains that come in from the Indian Ocean.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: In the past four decades, as the island adopted an aggressive development policy, its natural flood protection systems were built over, both by authorized and informal construction.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: “Flash flooding is now a frequent thing,” said N. S. Wijayaratne, deputy general manager for wetlands at the Sri Lanka Land Reclamation and Development Corporation, a government body.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Experts say Colombo’s long-neglected wetlands could help alleviate worsening floods - and are set to make a comeback as a key pillar of a major flood prevention program.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Floods occurred in 2016 and 2017 during the monsoon, and smaller deluges have happened this year even before the onset of the monsoon, including in the past few days.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Weather patterns have changed drastically since the 1970s, with rains becoming shorter but more intense, as the planet has warmed.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: That shift has raised the risk of flooding in the Colombo Metropolitan Area, home to about a quarter of the island nation’s population of 21 million.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: In November 2010, heavy rains brought the city to a standstill for a week, causing damage worth as much as $100 million, said World Bank consultant Nadeera Rajapakse Rubaroe.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: FAST-SHRINKING WETLANDS

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: The $321-million Metro Colombo Urban Development Project - about two-thirds of it funded by the World Bank - aims to strengthen flood protection and urban planning.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Under the plan, what is left of the city’s wetlands are being revived to retain excess water.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Two such areas have been developed in the past three years near a lake close to the city’s parliament building in the eastern suburbs of Baddagana and Diyasaru Thalawathugoda.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Wijayaratne said at least 10 more locations around the lake can be developed into similar parkland.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: There is no time to lose, say experts.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: “In terms of flood protection and mitigation, the wetlands in Colombo play an indispensable role, and are at an absolutely critical threshold,” the World Bank’s Rubaroe said.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: The city has been losing its wetlands at an alarming rate, she added.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Only about 17 percent of Colombo’s territory consists of wetlands that have not been encroached on, covering some 20 square km combined.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: That surface area can retain close to 40 percent of the rainfall the area receives annually - the equivalent of 27,000 Olympic swimming pools of water.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: If Colombo were to lose all its wetlands, flooding would shave off about 1 percent of its annual gross domestic product of some $53 billion, according to a World Bank study.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Projections by the bank and the government show that without the wetlands, major floods like the one in 2010 – which rose as high as 5 meters (16 ft) in some areas - could be 1.8 meters higher.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: PEOPLE’S PARKS

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: To be successful, experts say city communities must have a say in - and gain from - the rehabilitation of the wetlands.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: “People have to feel part and parcel of the project - they need to experience that these projects make very real changes to their lives,” said Sameera Premarathana, manager at Baddagana Park, which offers a nature trail for the public.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: The plan aims to develop the revivable wetlands around the parliament lake so that they offer recreational, tourist and other benefits, rather than leaving the land unused.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Premarathana said that when Baddagana Park first opened, local people showed little interest, and some even blamed the park for adding to floods in the area.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: But after the incidence of flooding reduced to almost nothing, they started to grasp the importance of the park, its manager said.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Local residents have also earned money from running the car park and providing refreshments for visitors, who number some 7,000 a month.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: The green space has become popular with school children on educational tours, with some joining the park conservation society.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Premarathana noted the full tourist potential of Colombo’s wetlands has been assessed at about 2 billion rupees ($12.7 million) per year.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: Wijayaratne of the Land Reclamation and Development Corporation said the wetland restoration projects would incorporate leisure and educational activities while ensuring rainwater run-off can still flow freely through the area.

column2: Colombo's wetlands float to top of flood prevention plan
column3: “The wellbeing of people in Colombo - especially in terms of flood protection - depends on its existing wetlands, and they need to be preserved and used wisely (and) sustainably as part and parcel of city development,” said Rubaroe.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: NANCHANG, July 18 (Xinhua) -- Holding a smartphone in his hand, He Xuehao, director of the flood control office in Anqing City, China's Anhui Province, knows everything about the city's real-time precipitation and hydrologic conditions.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Anqing is situated in the lower reaches of the Yangtze, China's longest river.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Every summer, flood season arrives just in time to worry flood control officials like He.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In the summer of 1998, China's Yangtze River flooded, causing more than 1,000 deaths.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Determining rising water levels is one of the biggest challenges for the flood control office.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: He still remembers that 20 years ago, when he was 16 years old, he had to patrol dikes every two hours, with a bamboo pole, a flashlight, and an umbrella, for days on end.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: "I had to row a boat and even swim to the mid-stream to measure water levels.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: It was troublesome and extremely dangerous," he said.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Thanks to the advancement of technology in flood control, officials like He no longer have to risk their lives to measure water levels.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: "The automatic observation and flood prediction system achieves full coverage of the Yangtze -- the mainstream, primary tributaries, large reservoirs, key medium reservoirs and lakes along the river," He said.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In Anqing alone, more than 600 stations measure and report rainfall automatically, and 210 water level gauging stations provide precise and timely monitoring data, which helps officials form and implement emergency plans.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In addition, a series of flood control equipment has been put into use.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In 2016, a collapsible mobile "water plugging wall" with a waterproof canvas bag at its core was used to fill dike breaches in Anqing.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In just 10 minutes, the "wall" can swell up to six meters, serving as a water barrier.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: "China has comprehensively strengthened its flood resistance ability in the past 20 years," He said.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: In 2010, flood control headquarters in neighboring Jiangxi Province used satellite remote sensing to evaluate flood situations and dispatch rescue teams to the worst-hit areas.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Two years later, drones were used to monitor water levels.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: This year, the province purchased five units of drainage equipment that can adapt to different environments such as cities and farmland.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Seven remote-control rescue robots also came into service in Jiangxi.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Shaped like lifeboats, these robots can evacuate three to four people stranded by the flood and deliver relief supplies.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: "We have set up a compete flood prevention communication system, which can automatically send warning messages to residents once it detects a potential risk of flood," said Wang Bin, secretary general of Huaihe River Flood Control Headquarters.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: "Technology improves prediction accuracy, increases rescue efficiency, and reduces losses caused by flooding."

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: Huaihe is another flood-prone river that originates from central China's Henan Province.

column2: China Focus: Technology enhances China's flood control ability - Xinhua
column3: With the advanced flood observation system and the introduction of cutting-edge equipment, floods are no longer as life-threatening as they were before, He added.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: (Reuters) - When Hurricane Michael barreled into the Florida Panhandle on Wednesday with 155-mph (249-kph) sustained winds, it defied forecasts made just two days beforehand, its wind speeds doubling since Monday and coming in just short of the highest category of intensity.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Palm trees are seen during Hurricane Michael in Panama City Beach, Florida, U.S. October 10, 2018.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: REUTERS/Jonathan Bachman

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Michael was not the only tropical cyclone in recent years to undergo what scientists refer to as “rapid intensification,” defined as an acceleration of wind speeds of at least 35 mph (56 kph) in 24 hours or less.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: The phenomenon has become more serious as sea waters have warmed with climate change.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: “It is most likely that the very warm water in the Gulf ... is likely contributing to the intensity and the intensification that we have seen,” said Jim Kossin, an atmospheric scientist with the U.S. National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Rapid intensification is dangerous because it gives businesses, industry and people on the ground less time to take appropriate precautions ahead of hurricanes like Michael that hit shore with far more furious winds than originally expected.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Several factors can contribute, but warmer waters increase the potential for a storm becoming stronger, climate scientists have said.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Climate change means that warmer ocean temperatures are being seen more often, said Jennie Evans, a professor of Meteorology at Pennsylvania State University.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: “Since we’ve got warm temperatures in the Gulf now, a hurricane has a much better chance to reach its maximum possible intensity, which appears to be what Michael is doing,” she said.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: In some cases, high-altitude winds can put a cap on a storm’s ability to draw power from moist sea air.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: But in Michael’s case, that brake was not in place.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Rapid intensification happens about 5 percent of the time and is difficult to predict.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Last year, in the Atlantic basin, forecasters correctly forecast six of 39 such instances, according to Michael Brennan, branch chief of the hurricane specialist unit at the U.S. National Hurricane Center.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: The NHC said last year it failed to adequately predict the rapid intensification of Hurricane Matthew in 2016 to a Category 5 storm with maximum sustained winds of 165 mph (270 kph).

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Matthew was directly responsible for 585 deaths, including more than 500 people in Haiti, the NHC said.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: While the science of tracking a storm relies heavily on data about conditions on its periphery, predicting intensity relies on measuring what is happening in the middle of it.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Typically, that means flying a hurricane hunter aircraft inside the storm, recording wind speeds from a weather buoy as a storm passes overhead or relying on satellites that may fly over once every other day.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: Collecting consistent data through the storm is difficult and limits the ability to predict intensity, hurricane experts have said.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: In recent storms that have intensified quickly, the phenomenon has been more exaggerated than in the past, according to a recent research paper co-authored by Pacific Northwest National Laboratory researcher Karthik Balaguru.

column2: Warm Gulf waters spawned Hurricane Michael's intensity: scientists
column3: “At the end of the day, deep warm water, what we call ocean heat content, that’s really the fuel supply for these storms,” said J. Marshall Shepherd, director of the atmospheric sciences program at the University of Georgia.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Four years ago this week, as American troops made their first, triumphant entrance into Baghdad, joyous Iraqis pulled down a giant statue of Saddam Hussein.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: It was powerful symbolism -- a murderous dictator toppled, Baghdadis taking to the streets without fear, American soldiers hailed as liberators.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: After four years of occupation, untold numbers killed by death squads and suicide bombers, and searing experiences like Abu Ghraib, few Iraqis still look on American soldiers as liberators.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Instead, thousands marked this week's anniversary by burning American flags and marching through the streets of Najaf chanting, ''Death to America.''

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Once again, tens of thousands of American troops are pouring into Baghdad.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Yesterday the Pentagon announced that battle-weary Army units in Iraq would have to stay on for an additional three months past their scheduled return dates.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Mr. Bush is desperately gambling that by stretching the Army to the absolute limits of its deployable strength, he may be able to impose some relative calm in the capital.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: And he seems to imagine that should that gamble succeed, the Shiite-dominated government of Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki will, without any serious pressure from Washington, take the steps toward sharing political power and economic resources it has tenaciously resisted since the day it took office a year ago.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Unless Mr. Maliki takes those steps -- eliminating militia and death squad members from the Iraqi Army and police, fairly sharing oil revenues, and rolling back laws that deny political and economic opportunities to the Sunni middle class -- no lasting security gains are possible.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: More Iraqi and American lives will be sacrificed.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Even among Shiites, who suffered so much at the hands of Saddam Hussein and who are the supposed beneficiaries of Mr. Maliki's shortsighted policies, there is a deep disillusionment and anger.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: This week, a Washington Post reporter interviewed Khadim al-Jubouri, who four years ago swung his sledgehammer to help knock down the dictator's statue.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Mr. Jubouri said that ever since he watched that statue being built he had nourished a dream of bringing it down and ushering in much better times.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Now, with friends and relatives killed, kidnapped or driven from their homes, the prices of basic necessities soaring and electricity rationed to four hours a day, Mr. Jubouri says the change of regimes ''achieved nothing'' and he has come to hate the American military presence he once welcomed.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Mr. Maliki's supporters can be even more frightening to listen to.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: This week's demonstration in Najaf was organized by the fiercely anti-American Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr, whose political party and militia helped put Mr. Maliki in power and are still among his most important allies.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: Two months into the Baghdad security drive, the gains Mr. Bush is banking on have not materialized.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: More American soldiers continue to arrive, and their commanders are talking about extending the troop buildup through the fall or into early next year.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: After four years, the political trend is even more discouraging.

column2: Four Years Later in Iraq
column3: There is no possible triumph in Iraq and very little hope left.

column3: The phenomenon has been prevailing in the tribal side of southern Egypt for decades or even generations, where family revenge killing equals honor, dignity and manhood, although most of the causes that triggered the enmity are often trivial, such as a quarrel about fighting kids, or a dispute over a phone recharge card.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: The norm in Upper Egypt is that when a family member is killed, the family buries the body but never holds a funeral until they kill the murderer or one of his dearest family members in revenge, and the blood feuds go on.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: Most of the village men involved in blood feuds live in the nearby mountains to escape either murder or arrest.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: Widows usually dress only in black for long years as a sign of mourning and they breastfeed their babies the desire for blood revenge, said Fathiya al-Essaily, a 70-year-old woman from "the village of widows," who lost both her husband and elder son in vendetta feuds.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: "A widow here would push her son for killing in revenge regardless of the consequences and the possible murder or escape of her son, because only then she would be no longer living in shame," the old lady told Xinhua at her one-storey home in Nag Ma'alla of Hugairat village in Qena.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: 62-year-old Mohamed Owais, also from Nag Ma'alla, lost both his brother and his 15-year-old nephew in a similar feud that represented "the most difficult moments" in his life.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: The blood feud, Owais continued, went on for several years until the Owais family accepted a reconciliation brokered by security authorities and popular reconciliation committees one and a half years ago.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: The tradition of reconciliation in a blood feud is a kind of ceremony watched by all villagers, where the one whose turn is to be killed walks to the family whose turn is to take revenge carrying his death shroud, a white garment, in his arms.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: He submissively and apologetically lies down in front of the man who is supposed to kill him as a sign of seeking forgiveness.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: His apology is always accepted because it is considered in Upper Egypt as shame for him and honor for the other family.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: Mahmoud Abdel-Mo'ez, a 65-year-old retired employee at the Ministry of Education, recalled the tragedy of losing his son during his wedding ceremony due to a vendetta feud and losing his wife who died out of grief over her son's death a few months later.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: An elementary school student in Hugairat village, whose parents conditioned not to mention his name, lamented that most teachers are reluctant to show up at school due to the many surrounding feuds, noting that most students drop education at some stage.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: "A lot of boys here learn how to carry guns since childhood," the boy continued with a sad tone.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: "I hope that we all carry pens rather than guns for the best interest of our village and nation."

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: Despite the cancerous tradition, the authorities, in cooperation with wise people through special committees, managed to achieve dozens of reconciliations and end bloodshed between big families over the past few years.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: "The security department in Qena, in cooperation with the governorate and the reconciliation committees, managed to achieve 100 reconciliations between feuding families in the past four years," said Qena's Deputy Security Chief Alaa al-Ayyat.

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: In the last two years, the police also seized more than 3,000 unlicensed guns with over 20,000 bullets in Qena province, which is known as "the capital of Upper Egypt's tribes."

column2: Feature: Authorities strive for clearing chronic tradition of blood feuds in southern Egypt - Xinhua
column3: For his part, Governor of Qena Abdel-Hamid al-Haggan said that the political leadership puts the elimination of blood feuds as one of its priorities in Upper Egypt, particularly in Qena.
